page.title: List of Lepidoptera that feed on brooms

revision.comment: Fix my error - what happened to bracket bot?
revision.text:
'''[[Broom (shrub)|Brooms]]''' (''[[Cytisus]]'', ''[[Genista]]'', etc.) are used as food plants by the [[larva]]e of a number of [[Lepidoptera]] species including:
==[[phagy|Monophagous]]== Species which feed exclusively on brooms
* [[Coleophoridae]] ** Several species of ''[[Coleophora]]'' case-bearers: *** ''[[Coleophora bilineatella|C. bilineatella]]'' - only on [[dyer's broom]] (''Genista tinctoria'') *** ''[[Coleophora genistae|C. genistae]]'' - only on ''[[Genista anglica]]'' *** ''[[Coleophora saturatella|C. saturatella]]'' *** ''[[Coleophora trifariella|C. trifariella]]'' *** ''[[Coleophora vibicella|C. vibicella]]'' - only on dyer's broom (''Genista tinctoria'')
==[[phagy|Polyphagous]]== Species which feed on brooms among other plants
* [[Arctiidae]] ** [[Garden tiger moth]] (''Arctia caja'') * [[Gelechiidae]] ** ''[[Chionodes distinctella]]'' * [[Geometridae]] ** [[Double-striped pug]] (''Gymnoscelis rufifasciata'') ** [[Engrailed (moth)|Engrailed]] (''Ectropis crepuscularia'') ** [[Mottled beauty]] (''Alcis repandata'') ** [[Streak (moth)|Streak]] (''Chesias legatella'') * [[Noctuidae]] ** [[Nutmeg (moth)|Nutmeg]] (''Discestra trifolii'')
==External links== *[http://www.nhm.ac.uk/our-science/data/hostplants/search/list.dsml?searchPageURL=index.dsml&PGenus=Cytisus&sort=Taxon "Search Results - Hostplant Genus: ''Cytisus''"] at ''HOSTS - a Database of the World's Lepidopteran Hostplants'' of the Natural History Museum, London. Retrieved 8 October 2017. *[http://www.nhm.ac.uk/our-science/data/hostplants/search/list.dsml?searchPageURL=index.dsml&PGenus=Genista&sort=Taxon "Search Results - Hostplant Genus: ''Genista''"] at ''HOSTS - a Database of the World's Lepidopteran Hostplants'' of the Natural History Museum, London. Retrieved 8 October 2017.
[[Category:Lists of Lepidoptera by food|Brooms]] [[Category:Genisteae|+Lepidoptera]]

page.title: List of Local Nature Reserves in Suffolk

revision.comment: Borough of St Edmundsbury
revision.text:
[[File:Gunton Warren 1.jpg|325px|thumb|A path down to the sea in [[Gunton Warren]] in [[Lowestoft]]|alt=Gunton Warren]] Suffolk is a county in [[East Anglia]]. It is bounded by [[Norfolk]] to the north, [[Cambridgeshire]] to the west and [[Essex]] to the south. With an area of {{convert|1,466 |mi2|km2}}, it is the eighth largest county in England,{{cite web|url=https://www.britishservices.co.uk/suffolk.htm|title=Suffolk|publisher=British Services|accessdate=20 August 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160508161754/http://www.britishservices.co.uk/suffolk.htm|archivedate=8 May 2016|df=}} and in mid-2016 the population was 745,000.{{cite web|url=https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/populationandmigration/populationestimates/datasets/populationestimatesforukenglandandwalesscotlandandnorthernireland|title=Population Estimates for UK, England and Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland: Mid 2016|publisher=Office for National Statistics|accessdate=20 August 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170215062115/https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/populationandmigration/populationestimates/datasets/populationestimatesforukenglandandwalesscotlandandnorthernireland|archivedate=15 February 2017|df=}} At the top level of local government is [[Suffolk County Council]], and below it are seven borough and district councils: [[Babergh]], [[Forest Heath]], [[Ipswich]], [[Mid Suffolk]], [[Borough of St Edmundsbury|St Edmundsbury]], [[Suffolk Coastal]] and [[Waveney District|Waveney]].{{cite web|url=https://www.suffolk.gov.uk/council-and-democracy/borough-district-parish-and-town-councils/|title=Borough, District, Parish and Town Councils|publisher=Suffolk County Council|accessdate=20 August 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160527160959/http://www.suffolk.gov.uk/council-and-democracy/borough-district-parish-and-town-councils/|archivedate=27 May 2016|df=}} Much of the coast consists of the estuaries of the [[River Orwell|Orwell]], [[River Stour, Suffolk|Stour]], [[River Alde|Alde]], [[River Deben|Deben]] and [[River Blyth, Suffolk|Blyth]] rivers, with large areas of wetlands and marshes. Agriculture and shipping play a major role in the county's economy. [[Local Nature Reserve]]s (LNRs) are designated by local authorities under the [[National Parks and Access to the Countryside Act 1949]]. The local authority must have a legal control over the site, by owning or leasing it or having an agreement with the owner. LNRs are sites which have a special local interest either biologically or geologically, and local authorities have a duty to care for them. They can apply local [[Byelaws in the United Kingdom|bye-laws]] to manage and protect LNRs.{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/protected-or-designated-areas|title=Protected or Designated Areas|date=9 April 2013|publisher=Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs and Natural England|accessdate=29 July 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504145328/https://www.gov.uk/protected-or-designated-areas|archivedate=4 May 2015|df=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/create-and-manage-local-nature-reserves|title=Local Nature Reserves: Setting up and Management|date=2 October 2014|publisher=Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs and Natural England|accessdate=29 July 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150704111109/https://www.gov.uk/create-and-manage-local-nature-reserves|archivedate=4 July 2015|df=}} {{As of|2017|08}} there are 36 LNRs in the county. Three are in [[Areas of Outstanding Natural Beauty]], seven are [[Sites of Special Scientific Interest]], one is a ''[[Nature Conservation Review]]'' site and two are managed by the [[Suffolk Wildlife Trust]]. The largest LNR is [[Sudbury Common Lands]] with {{convert| 50.3 |ha|acre}}, which has ancient wetlands, and the smallest is [[Alderman Canal West]] at {{convert| 1.0 |ha|acre}}, which has rare wetland flora. {{kml}} ==Key== ===Other classifications=== *'''DVAONB''' = [[Dedham Vale]] [[Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty]] *'''NCR''' = ''[[Nature Conservation Review]]'' *'''SCHAONB''' = [[Suffolk Coast and Heaths]] [[Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty]] * '''SWT''' = [[Suffolk Wildlife Trust]] * '''SSSI''' = [[Site of Special Scientific Interest]] ==Sites== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" !scope="col" | Site !scope="col" class="unsortable" | Photograph !scope="col" data-sort-type="number"| Area{{efn|The area is taken from the Natural England map of each site. (Click on the identify icon ('''i''') in the "Feature Tools" and then click on the site.)}} !scope="col" | Location{{efn|Unless otherwise stated, the location is taken from the Natural England details page for the site.}} !scope="col" | District !scope="col" | Other classifications !scope="col" class="unsortable" | Map{{efn|The maps are on the Natural England database of Local Nature Reserves.}} !scope="col" class="unsortable" | Details{{efn|Details are on the pages on each site in the Natural England database of Local Nature Reserves.{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_results.asp?N=&C=38&Submit=Search|title=Local Nature Reserves: Search Results for Suffolk|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=26 April 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428052022/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_results.asp?N=&C=38&Submit=Search|archivedate=28 April 2017|df=}} }} !scope="col" class="unsortable" | Description |- ! scope="row"|[[Alderman Canal East]] |[[File:Alderman canal local nature reserve - geograph.org.uk - 1305072.jpg|100px|alt=Alderman Canal East]] |{{convert| 1.6 |ha|acre}} | [[Ipswich]]
{{coord| 52.057 | 1.142 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Alderman Canal East }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TM 155 445 }} |[[Ipswich]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009317%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=585 Details] |A path runs a long a canalised part of the [[River Gipping]], and the site also has reedbeds, a ditch and grassland with tall herbs. There are uncommon wetland flora, and birds include [[spotted flycatcher]]s, [[kingfisher]]s and [[reed bunting]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=585|title=Alderman Canal East|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|date=26 March 2013|accessdate=13 July 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428052846/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=585|archivedate=28 April 2017|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Alderman Canal West]] |[[File:Footpath alongside the disused Alderman canal - geograph.org.uk - 1305103.jpg|100px|alt=Alderman Canal West]] |{{convert| 1.0 |ha|acre}} | [[Ipswich]]
{{coord| 52.055 | 1.14 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Alderman Canal West}}
{{gbmappingsmall| TM 154 443 }} |[[Ipswich]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009637%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=1499 Details] |Paths run along the canal and through reedbeds. There is also grassland with tall herbs, and the canal bank has rare wetland flora. Birds include [[kingfisher]]s and [[reed bunting]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=1499|title=Alderman Canal West|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|date=26 March 2017|accessdate=17 July 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428052716/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=1499|archivedate=28 April 2017|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Arger Fen]] |[[File:Arger Fen.jpg|100px|alt=Arger Fen]] |{{convert| 17.6 |ha|acre}} | [[Assington]]
{{coord| 51.983 |0.813 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Arger Fen}}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 933 354 }} |[[Babergh]] |[[Dedham Vale|DVAONB]],{{cite web|url=http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/node/15776|title=Wildlife at Arger Fen & Spouse's Vale|publisher=Suffolk Wildlife Trust|accessdate=4 May 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170802210514/http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/node/15776|archivedate=2017-08-02|df=}} [[SSSI]],{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002262&SiteName=arger&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Arger Fen |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 4 May 2017 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170802204400/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002262&SiteName=arger&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate= 2 August 2017 |df= }} [[Suffolk Wildlife Trust|SWT]]{{cite web |url= http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/argerfen |title= Arger Fen & Spouse's Vale |publisher= Suffolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate= 28 April 2017 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160426071409/http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/argerfen |archivedate= 2016-04-26 |df= }} |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271008750%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=11 Details] |This site has ancient woodland and wet meadows. There is a diverse range of tree species, including [[Prunus avium|wild cherry]], [[field maple]] and [[crab apple]]. Uncommon fauna include [[hazel dormouse|hazel dormice]] and [[barbastelle bat]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=11|title=Arger Fen|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|date=26 March 2013|accessdate=17 July 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428142504/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=11|archivedate=28 April 2017|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Aspal Close]] |[[File:Aspal Close 3.jpg|100px|alt=Aspal Close]] |{{convert| 18.9 |ha|acre}} | [[Beck Row]]
{{coord|52.369 | 0.493 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Aspall Close }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 698 775 }} |[[Forest Heath]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009614%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=806 Details] |This site has grassland, woodland and scrub. Almost 300 plant and six bat species have been recorded,{{cite web |url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=806 |title=Aspall (sic) Close |series=Local Nature Reserves |publisher=Natural England |date=26 March 2013 |accessdate=5 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428052609/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=806 |archivedate=28 April 2017 |df= }} and there are around 200 ancient oaks, some of which may be 1,000 years old. There are a car park and a football pitch.{{cite web|url=http://www.fieldsintrust.org/Aspal-Close-Local-Nature-Reserve|title=Aspal Close Local Nature Reserve|publisher=Fields in Trust|accessdate=5 June 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160926194936/http://www.fieldsintrust.org/Aspal-Close-Local-Nature-Reserve|archivedate=26 September 2016|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Barton Mills Valley]] |[[File:Barton Mills Valley 1.jpg|100px|alt=Barton Mills Valley]] |{{convert| 10.7 |ha|acre}} | [[Mildenhall, Suffolk|Mildenhall]]
{{coord| 52.337 |0.525 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Barton Mills Valley }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 721 740 }} |[[Forest Heath]] |[[SSSI]]{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S2000443&SiteName=breckland&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Breckland Forest |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 23 May 2017 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170820224631/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S2000443&SiteName=breckland&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate= 20 August 2017 |df= }} |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271008770%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=1138 Details] |This diverse site has reedbeds, [[alder carr]], willow carr and [[Cyperaceae|sedge areas]]. There are picnic benches, a car park and disabled access.{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=1138|title=Barton Mills Valley|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|date=26 March 2013|accessdate=5 June 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428051851/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=1138|archivedate=28 April 2017|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Bixley Heath]] |[[File:Bixley Heath 3.jpg|100px|alt=Bixley Heath]] |{{convert| 5.1 |ha|acre}} | [[Ipswich]]
{{coord| 52.042 |1.205 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Bixley Heath }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TM 199 430 }} |[[Ipswich]] |[[SSSI]]{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1006085&SiteName=bixley&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Bixley Heath |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 4 May 2017 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170820224633/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1006085&SiteName=bixley&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate= 20 August 2017 |df= }} |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009319%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=587 Details] |This site has areas of dry heath on high ground and swamp in a valley bottom. The heath is dominated by [[common heather]], and other plants include [[bell heather]] and [[sheep's fescue]]. There is a dense stand of [[lesser pond-sedge]] in the swamp.{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1006085.pdf|title=Bixley Heath citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=20 August 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150504193639/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1006085.pdf|archivedate=4 May 2015|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Bobbits Lane]] |[[File:Meadow, reeds and willows by Belstead Brook - geograph.org.uk - 1001575.jpg|100px|alt=Bobbits Lane]] |{{convert| 16.1 |ha|acre}} | [[Ipswich]]
{{coord| 52.03 |1.128 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Bobbits Lane }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TM 147 415 }} |[[Ipswich]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271123047%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=1134 Details] |Grassy paths run through these wet meadows. Fauna include [[otter]]s, [[European water vole|water voles]], [[kingfisher]]s, [[egret]]s and [[toad]]s.{{cite web |url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=1134 |title=Bobbits Lane |series=Local Nature Reserves |publisher=Natural England |date=26 March 2013 |accessdate=17 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428142501/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=1134 |archivedate=28 April 2017 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Bourne Park Reed Beds]] |[[File:Bourne Park Reed Beds 3.jpg|100px|alt=Bourne Park Reed Beds]] |{{convert| 7.4 |ha|acre}} | [[Ipswich]]
{{coord| 52.032 | 1.139 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Bourne Park Reed Beds }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TM 154 417 }} |[[Ipswich]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009316%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=584 Details] |This nature reserve in Bourne Park is a linear area of reed beds, scrub woodland and tall herb fen, along the north bank of [[Belstead Brook]].{{cite web|url= http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=584|title= Bourne Park Reed Beds|series= Local Nature Reserves|publisher= Natural England|date= 26 March 2013|accessdate= 13 August 2017|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170428053121/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=584|archivedate= 28 April 2017|df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Bramford Meadows]] |[[File:Bramford Meadows 3.jpg|100px|alt=Bramford Meadows]] |{{convert| 9.0 |ha|acre}} | [[Bramford]]
{{coord| 52.076 | 1.104 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Bramford Meadows }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TM 128 465 }} |[[Mid Suffolk]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271008799%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=60 Details] |This site on the east bank of the [[River Gipping]] has grassland and scrub, and it is crossed by wet ditches and the former course of the river. Flora in the ditches include [[Myosotis scorpioides|water forget me not]], [[water mint]], [[brooklime]] and [[Scrophularia auriculata|water figwort]].{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=60|title=Bramford Meadows|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|date=2 June 2017|accessdate=25 July 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428052908/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=60|archivedate=28 April 2017|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Bridge Wood]] |[[File:Bridge Wood 5.jpg|100px|alt=Bridge Wood]] |{{convert| 31.0 |ha|acre}} | [[Ipswich]]
{{coord| 52.019 | 1.184 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Bridge Wood }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TM 186 404 }} |[[Ipswich]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009318%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=586 Details] |This site has been managed as woodland at least since 1600, and it has several ancient [[oak]]s. There are also areas of pine, which are being thinned to create a more mixed woodland.{{cite web |url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=586 |title=Bridge Wood |series=Local Nature Reserves |publisher=Natural England |date=27 October 2016 |accessdate=13 August 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428052606/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=586 |archivedate=28 April 2017 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Broom Hill, Hadleigh]] |[[File:Broom Hill, Hadleigh 6.jpg|100px|alt=Broom Hill]] |{{convert| 3.9 |ha|acre}} | [[Hadleigh, Suffolk|Hadleigh]]
{{coord| 52.043 |0.944 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Broom Hill, Hadleigh }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TM 020 424 }} |[[Babergh]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271008810%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=71 Details] |This former quarry is now covered with woodland, grassland and scrub. There are many ancient trees, together with [[Pollarding|pollarded]] [[oak]]s and [[small-leaved lime]]s, which had high branches removed, and [[coppice]]d [[hazel]] and [[Tilia|lime]] trees, which were cut at ground level.{{cite web|url=http://www.midsuffolk.gov.uk/communities/open-spaces-and-playgrounds/places-to-visit/sites-in-and-around-hadleigh/|title=Sites in and around Hadleigh|publisher=Mid Suffolk District Council|accessdate=7 August 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170807192519/http://www.midsuffolk.gov.uk/communities/open-spaces-and-playgrounds/places-to-visit/sites-in-and-around-hadleigh/|archivedate=7 August 2017|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Church Meadow]] |[[File:Church Meadow local nature reserve - geograph.org.uk - 997123 cropped.jpg|100px|alt=Church Meadow]] |{{convert| 3.8 |ha|acre}} | [[Stowmarket]]

{{gbmappingsmall| TM 050 570 }} |[[Mid Suffolk]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271008840%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=101 Details] |This was formerly the garden of Combs Hall, which was demolished in 1756. The meadow is grazed by sheep.{{cite web|url=http://www.midsuffolk.gov.uk/assets/Realm-Public/ChurchMeadow080104.pdf|title=Church Meadow Local Nature Reserve|publisher=Mid Suffolk District Council|accessdate=25 July 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170820224632/http://www.midsuffolk.gov.uk/assets/Realm-Public/ChurchMeadow080104.pdf|archivedate=20 August 2017|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|{{sortname|The| Dales Open Space|The Dales Open Space}} |[[File:The Dales Open Space 6.jpg|100px|alt=The Dales Open Space]] |{{convert| 5.9 |ha|acre}} | [[Ipswich]]

In the north the site is a flat valley bottom, and it slopes up steeply in the south.{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=1135|title=The Dales Open Space|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|date=27 March 2013|accessdate=20 August 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428052925/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=1135|archivedate=28 April 2017|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Fen Alder Carr]] |[[File:Fen Alder Carr local nature reserve - geograph.org.uk - 597915.jpg|100px|alt=Fen Alder Carr]] |{{convert| 1.7 |ha|acre}} | [[Stowmarket]]

{{gbmappingsmall| TM 547 959 }} |[[Waveney District|Waveney]] |[[Suffolk Wildlife Trust|SWT]]{{cite web |url= http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/reserves/gunton-warren |title= Gunton Warren |publisher= Suffolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate= 27 April 2017 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170428052144/http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/reserves/gunton-warren |archivedate= 28 April 2017 |df= }} |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271008929%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=191 Details] |Gunton Warren is a coastal site which has sand dunes, shingle, lowland heath and cliff slopes. Corton Woods has mature trees and diverse flora such as [[lesser celandine]], [[Ophrys apifera|bee orchids]] and [[common spotted orchid]]s.Noticeboard on Corton Wood |- ! scope="row"|[[Gunton Wood]] |[[File:Gunton Wood 5.jpg|100px|alt=Gunton Wood]] |{{convert| 2.8 |ha|acre}} | [[Lowestoft]]

{{gbmappingsmall| TM 531 933 }} |[[Waveney District|Waveney]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271008995%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=258 Details] |In the medieval period this site was [[turbary]], an area which was dug for peat, and it later flooded and became a lake.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=ho_gDQAAQBAJ&pg=PA47&lpg=PA47&dq=%22Leathes+Ham%22#v=onepage&q=%22Leathes%20Ham%22&f=false|title=Medieval Lowestoft: The Origins and Growth of a Suffolk Coastal Community|page=47|first=David|last=Butcher|publisher=Boydell & Brewer|year=2016|isbn=9781783271498|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170820224630/https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=ho_gDQAAQBAJ&pg=PA47&lpg=PA47&dq=%22Leathes%20Ham%22&source=bl&ots=NTwIitCTTU&sig=AHQ4jf_KOlhb5_s4YNjp_lEXIqk&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj3iuT_5uPTAhVHCpoKHXdDCgE4FBDoAQgiMAA#v=onepage&q=%22Leathes%20Ham%22&f=false|archivedate=2017-08-20|df=}} It has a reedbed, dykes, and marshes where wildfowl breed. Flora include [[ragged robin]] and [[southern marsh orchid]].{{cite web |url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=258 |title=Leathes Ham |series=Local Nature Reserves |publisher=Natural England |date=27 March 2013 |accessdate=9 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428052534/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=258 |archivedate=28 April 2017 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Maidscross Hill]] |[[File:Gravel pit at Maids Cross Hill - geograph.org.uk - 464006.jpg|100px|alt=Maidscross Hill]] |{{convert| 49.8 |ha|acre}} | [[Brandon, Suffolk|Brandon]]

{{gbmappingsmall| TL 728 823 }} |[[Forest Heath]] |[[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]],{{cite book|editor-first=Derek |editor-last=Ratcliffe |title=A Nature Conservation Review|volume=2 |page=135 |editorlink=Derek Ratcliffe |publisher= Cambridge University Press|location =Cambridge, UK |year=1977|isbn= 0521 21403 3 }} [[SSSI]]{{cite web |url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000672&SiteName=maidscross&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Maidscross Hill |series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher= Natural England |accessdate= 4 May 2017 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170820224634/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000672&SiteName=maidscross&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |archivedate= 20 August 2017 |df= }} |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271082983%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=949 Details] |This very dry grassland has four nationally rare plants, [[Thymus serpyllum|Breckland wild thyme]], [[Silene otites|Spanish catchfly]], [[grape hyacinth]] and [[sickle medick]]. There are many flowers in the spring such as bluebells, wild garlic and archangel.{{cite web |url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=1476 |title=Millennium Wood |series=Local Nature Reserves |publisher=Natural England |date= |accessdate=14 August 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428052951/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=1476 |archivedate=28 April 2017 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Moreton Hall Community Woods]] |[[File:Moreton Hall Community Woods 6.jpg|100px|alt=Moreton Hall Community Woods]] |{{convert| 18.5 |ha|acre}} | [[Bury St Edmunds]]
{{coord| 52.248 | 0.733 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Moreton Hall Community Woods }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 867 646 }} |[[Borough of St Edmundsbury|St Edmundsbury]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271082984%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=950 Details] |This site in six separate areas has woodland, grassland, a pond, paths and cycleways.{{cite web |url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=950 |title=Moreton Hall Community Woods |series=Local Nature Reserves |publisher=Natural England |date=27 March 2013 |accessdate=11 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428142303/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=950 |archivedate=28 April 2017 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Needham Lake]] |[[File:Needham Lake - geograph.org.uk - 1276145.jpg|100px|alt=Needham Lake]] |{{convert| 9.9 |ha|acre}} | [[Needham Market]]
{{coord| 52.153 | 1.06 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Needham Lake }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TM 094 549 }} |[[Mid Suffolk]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009043%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=307 Details] |The lake is in former sand and gravel workings. It has diverse fauna and flora in aquatic, marsh and scrub habitats. There are grass and tarmac paths.{{cite web |url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=307 |title=Needham Lake |series=Local Nature Reserves |publisher=Natural England |date=27 March 2013 |accessdate=1 August 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428052429/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=307 |archivedate=28 April 2017 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|{{sortname|The| Pennings, Eye|The Pennings, Eye}} |[[File:The Pennings, Eye 6.jpg|100px|alt=The Pennings]] |{{convert| 2.7 |ha|acre}} | [[Bury St Edmunds]]
{{coord| 52.319 | 1.153 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=The Pennings, Eye }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TM 150 736 }} |[[Mid Suffolk]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009195%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=460 Details] |This site on the east bank of the [[River Dove, Suffolk|River Dove]] is managed as a hay meadow. Fauna on the river bank include [[Common kingfisher|kingfishers]] and [[European water vole|water voles]].{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=460|title=The Pennings, Eye|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|date=3 January 2014|accessdate=3 July 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428052611/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=460|archivedate=28 April 2017|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Pipers Vale]] |[[File:Pipers Vale 2.jpg|100px|alt=Pipers Vale]] |{{convert| 19.7 |ha|acre}} | [[Ipswich]]
{{coord| 52.028 | 1.173 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Pipers Vale }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TM 178 414 }} |[[Ipswich]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009315%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=583 Details] |This site on the bank of the [[River Orwell]] is part of [[Orwell Country Park]]. Its diverse habitats include heath, reedbeds, scrub and [[alder carr]]. Over 100 bird species have been recorded, including [[redwing]]s, [[whimbrel]]s and [[bullfinch]]es.{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=583|title=Pipers Vale|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|date=27 March 2013|accessdate=14 August 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428142459/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=583|archivedate=28 April 2017|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Railway Walk, Hadleigh]] |[[File:Hadleigh Railway Walk - geograph.org.uk - 1370611.jpg|100px|alt=Hadleigh Railway Walk]] |{{convert| 11.6 |ha|acre}} | [[Hadleigh, Suffolk|Hadleigh]]
{{coord| 52.03 |0.98 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Hadleigh Railway Walk }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TM 046 409 }} |[[Babergh]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009093%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=357 Details] |The walk starts at the original station building in Hadleigh, which is now a private house. The route goes along a flat path, some of it on raised banks and other parts on downward slopes. Most of it is bordered by trees.{{cite web |url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=357 |title=Railway Walk, Hadleigh |series=Local Nature Reserves |publisher=Natural England |date=27 March 2013 |accessdate=1 August 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428053124/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=357 |archivedate=28 April 2017 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|{{sortname|The| Railway Walks|The Railway Walks}} |[[File:Rodbridge Picnic Site - geograph.org.uk - 1464337.jpg|100px|alt=The Railway Walks]] |{{convert| 25.3 |ha|acre}} | [[Sudbury, Suffolk|Sudbury]]
{{coord| 52.1 | 0.8 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= The Railway Walks }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 857 435 }} |[[Babergh]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009909%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=951 Details] |The walk has diverse fauna and flora in habitats such as water meadows, streams, ditches and ponds.{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=951|title=The Railway Walks|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|date=28 March 2013|accessdate=1 August 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428052714/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=951|archivedate=28 April 2017|df=}} Birds include [[willow warbler]]s, [[kingfisher]]s, [[woodpecker]]s, [[mallard]]s, [[moorhen]]s and [[swan]]s.{{cite journal|journal=East Anglian Times|first=David|last=Falk|title=Walk: Sudbury's Valley Trail|date=23 May 2011|url=http://www.suffolkmag.co.uk/out-about/walks/walk-sudbury-s-valley-trail-1-1644934|accessdate=1 August 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170801164619/http://www.suffolkmag.co.uk/out-about/walks/walk-sudbury-s-valley-trail-1-1644934|archivedate=1 August 2017|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Rede Wood]] |[[File:Rede Wood, Henley - geograph.org.uk - 290363.jpg|100px|alt=Rede Wood]] |{{convert| 7.5 |ha|acre}} | [[Ipswich]]
{{coord| 52.112 | 1.143 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Rede Wood }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TM 153 506 }} |[[Mid Suffolk]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009908%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=932 Details] |This semi-natural wood on [[boulder clay]] is mainly [[pedunculate oak]] and [[Fraxinus|ash]], with a coppiced understorey mainly of [[hazel]]. The flora include 38 species indicative of ancient woodland.{{cite web |url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=932 |title=Rede Wood |series=Local Nature Reserves |publisher=Natural England |date=27 March 2013 |accessdate=1 August 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428051803/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=932 |archivedate=28 April 2017 |df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Riverside Walk, Hadleigh]] |[[File:Riverside Walk, Hadleigh 1.jpg|100px|alt=Riverside Walk]] |{{convert| 4.6 |ha|acre}} | [[Hadleigh, Suffolk|Hadleigh]]
{{coord| 52.043 |0.948 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Riverside Walk, Hadleigh }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TM 023 424 }} |[[Babergh]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009102%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=366 Details] |This linear site on the west bank of the [[River Brett]] comprises two footpaths and the [[alder]] woodland and fen between them. [[Great willowherb]] and [[meadowsweet]] grow in marshy silted up ditches, and birds include [[warbler]]s and [[finch]]es.{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=366|title=Riverside Walk, Hadleigh|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|date=27 March 2013|accessdate=7 August 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428052357/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=366|archivedate=28 April 2017|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Sandlings]] |[[File:Sandlings 6.jpg|100px|alt=Sandlings]] |{{convert| 5.7 |ha|acre}} | [[Ipswich]]
{{coord| 52.056 |1.213 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Sandlings }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TM 204 445 }} |[[Suffolk Coastal]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271452097%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=1539 Details] |This site has [[acid grassland]], a wildflower meadow and areas of scrub. Nearly 70 species of bird have been observed and 22 of butterfly, including the [[white-letter hairstreak]].{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=1539|title=Sandlings|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|date=27 March 2013|accessdate=20 August 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428142419/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=1539|archivedate=28 April 2017|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Spring Wood, Belstead]] |[[File:Spring Wood, Belstead 6.jpg|100px|alt=Spring Wood]] |{{convert| 5.5 |ha|acre}} | [[Ipswich]]
{{coord| 52.029 | 1.124 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Spring Wood, Belstead }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TM 144 413 }} |[[Ipswich]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009156%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=1136 Details] |This ancient [[oak]] and [[hornbeam]] wood has an understorey of [[hazel]]. There are [[small-leaved lime]]s in groups several metres in diameter, which are genetically one tree, as a result of coppicing decades ago.{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=1136|title=Spring Wood, Belstead|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|date=27 March 2013|accessdate=14 August 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428051938/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=1136|archivedate=28 April 2017|df=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.ipswich.gov.uk/sites/default/files/icd26a_-_lwn-autumn-2015.pdf|page=6|first=Alison|last=Mackay|title=Local Wildlife News|date=September–December 2015|publisher=Ipswich Borough Council|accessdate=14 August 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170814215010/https://www.ipswich.gov.uk/sites/default/files/icd26a_-_lwn-autumn-2015.pdf|archivedate=14 August 2017|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Stoke Park Wood]] |[[File:Stoke Park Wood 6.jpg|100px|alt=Stoke Park Wood]] |{{convert| 2.2 |ha|acre}} | [[Ipswich]]
{{coord| 52.034 | 1.133 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Stoke Park Wood }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TM 150 419 }} |[[Ipswich]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271123049%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=1137 Details] |This ancient wood was formerly part of the Stoke Park estate, and it still has the remains of a Victorian drainage system. It was formerly called Fishpond Covert as it had a large fishpond. It is a mixed woodland with grass trails and glades.{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=1137|title=Stoke Park Wood|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|date=27 March 2017|accessdate=14 August 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428051321/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=1137|archivedate=28 April 2017|df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Sudbury Common Lands]] |[[File:Stream, Sudbury common lands - geograph.org.uk - 626759.jpg|100px|alt=Sudbury Common Lands]] |{{convert| 50.3 |ha|acre}} | [[Sudbury, Suffolk|Sudbury]]
{{coord| 52.04 |0.72 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Sudbury Common Lands }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 868 417 }} |[[Babergh]] | |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009176%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=441 Details] |This site has ancient wetland with ponds and ditches, and there are locally uncommon species such as [[flowering rush]], tubular [[water dropwort]] and [[Juncus compressus|round-fruited rush]]. There is also grassland which has never been ploughed, and it has diverse grasses and wildflowers.{{cite web|url= http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=441|title= Sudbury Common Lands|series= Local Nature Reserves|publisher= Natural England|date= 27 March 2017|accessdate= 2 August 2017|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170428052502/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=441|archivedate= 28 April 2017|df= }} |- ! scope="row"|[[Tiger Hill, Suffolk|Tiger Hill]] |[[File:Entrance to Tiger Hill Wood - geograph.org.uk - 373955.jpg|100px|alt=Tiger Hill]] |{{convert| 21.0 |ha|acre}} | [[Assington]]
{{coord| 51.986 | 0.805 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Tiger Hill }}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 927 357 }} |[[Babergh]] |[[Dedham Vale|DVAONB]],{{cite web|url=http://www.dedhamvalestourvalley.org/assets/Publications/Biodiversity/Tiger-Hill-leaflet-revised-April-2016.pdf|title=Tiger Hill|publisher=Dedham Valley Area of Outstanding Natural Valley and Stour Valley Project|accessdate=4 May 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170820224630/http://www.dedhamvalestourvalley.org/assets/Publications/Biodiversity/Tiger-Hill-leaflet-revised-April-2016.pdf|archivedate=20 August 2017|df=}} [[SSSI]] |[http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=lnrIndex&query=REF_CODE%3D%271009204%27 Map] |[http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=469 Details] |This site has woodland, heath and fenland, and fauna include [[badger]]s, [[bat]]s and rare and endangered [[dormice]].{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=469|title=Tiger Hill|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|date=28 March 2013|accessdate=2 August 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170428053116/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=38&N=&ID=469|archivedate=28 April 2017|df=}} |} ==See also== *[[National Nature Reserves in Suffolk]] *[[Suffolk Wildlife Trust]] *[[List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Suffolk]] ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{coord|52|10|N|1|0|E|region:GB_type:adm1st|display=title|name=Suffolk}} {{Local Nature Reserves in Suffolk}} {{LNR lists}} {{featured list}} [[Category:Local nature reserves in England|Suffolk]] [[Category:Lists of Local Nature Reserves|Suffolk]] [[Category:Local Nature Reserves in Suffolk| ]]

page.title: List of oil fields of Montana

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Energy-related lists]]; added [[Category:Lists of oil and natural gas fields]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{GeoGroupTemplate}} There are at least '''45 named [[oil field]]s in [[Montana]]''' according to the [[U.S. Geological Survey]], Board of Geographic Names. The USGS defines ''oil field'' as: "Area where petroleum is or was removed from the Earth."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://geonames.usgs.gov/pls/gnispublic/f?p=154:8:2386825790526740 |title=U.S. Geographic Names Information System-Feature Class Definition |publisher=U.S. Geological Survey |accessdate=2011-07-26}}</ref>
An '''oil field''' is a region with an abundance of [[oil well]]s extracting [[petroleum]] (crude oil) from below ground. Because the [[oil reservoir]]s typically extend over a large area, possibly several hundred kilometres across, full exploitation entails multiple wells scattered across the area. In addition, there may be exploratory wells probing the edges, pipelines to transport the oil elsewhere, and support facilities.
The [[Schlumberger]] Oilfield Glossary defines ''oil field'' as: "An accumulation, pool or group of pools of oil in the subsurface. An oil field consists of a reservoir in a shape that will trap hydrocarbons and that is covered by an impermeable or sealing rock. Typically, industry professionals use the term with an implied assumption of economic size."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.glossary.oilfield.slb.com/ |title=Schlumberger Oil Glossary |accessdate=2011-07-26}}</ref>
* [[Arch Apex Gas Field]], [[Toole County, Montana]], {{coord|48|54|27|N|111|21|32|W|display=inline|name=Arch Apex Gas Field}}, el. {{convert|4039|ft|m}} <ref>{{cite gnis |id=768323|name=Arch Apex Gas Field}}</ref> * [[Bascom Oil Field]], [[Rosebud County, Montana]], {{coord|46|39|08|N|107|47|25|W|display=inline|name=Bascom Oil Field}}, el. {{convert|2838|ft|m}} <ref>{{cite gnis |id=768538|name=Bascom Oil Field}}</ref> * [[Bears Den Oil and Gas Field]], [[Liberty County, Montana]], {{coord|48|52|43|N|111|00|12|W|display=inline|name=Bears Den Oil and Gas Field}}, el. {{convert|4101|ft|m}} <ref>{{cite gnis |id=768616|name=Bears Den Oil and Gas Field}}</ref> * [[Belle Creek Oil Field]], [[Powder River County, Montana]], {{coord|45|06|33|N|105|05|06|W|display=inline|name=Belle Creek Oil Field}}, el. {{convert|3638|ft|m}} <ref>{{cite gnis |id=2701844|name=Belle Creek Oil Field}}</ref> * [[Big Wall Oil Field]], [[Musselshell County, Montana]], {{coord|46|37|00|N|108|22|47|W|display=inline|name=Big Wall Oil Field}}, el. {{convert|3291|ft|m}} <ref>{{cite gnis |id=768833|name=Big Wall Oil Field}}</ref> * [[Bowes Oil Field]], [[Blaine County, Montana]], {{coord|48|28|43|N|109|14|25|W|display=inline|name=Bowes Oil Field}}, el. {{convert|3015|ft|m}} <ref>{{cite gnis |id=769140|name=Bowes Oil Field}}</ref> * [[Brorson Oil Field]], [[Richland County, Montana]], {{coord|47|47|58|N|104|18|03|W|display=inline|name=Brorson Oil Field}}, el. {{convert|2428|ft|m}} <ref>{{cite gnis |id=769254|name=Brorson Oil Field}}</ref> * [[Cabin Creek Oil Field]], [[Fallon County, Montana]], {{coord|46|36|25|N|104|27|26|W|display=inline|name=Cabin Creek Oil Field}}, el. {{convert|2848|ft|m}} <ref>{{cite gnis |id=799210|name=Cabin Creek Oil Field}}</ref> * [[Cupton Oil Field]], [[Fallon County, Montana]], {{coord|46|32|58|N|104|18|32|W|display=inline|name=Cupton Oil Field}}, el. {{convert|3018|ft|m}} <ref>{{cite gnis |id=799216|name=Cupton Oil Field}}</ref> * [[Devon Gas Field]], [[Toole County, Montana]], {{coord|48|34|44|N|111|29|21|W|display=inline|name=Devon Gas Field}}, el. {{convert|3317|ft|m}} <ref>{{cite gnis |id=770635|name=Devon Gas Field}}</ref> * [[East Poplar Oil Field]], [[Roosevelt County, Montana]], {{coord|48|12|26|N|105|06|16|W|display=inline|name=East Poplar Oil Field}}, el. {{convert|2110|ft|m}} <ref>{{cite gnis |id=771100|name=East Poplar Oil Field}}</ref> * [[Elk Basin Oil Field]], [[Carbon County, Montana]], {{coord|45|01|04|N|108|54|33|W|display=inline|name=Elk Basin Oil Field}}, el. {{convert|4393|ft|m}} <ref>{{cite gnis |id=771181|name=Elk Basin Oil Field}}</ref> * [[Flat Coulee Oil and Gas Field]], [[Liberty County, Montana]], {{coord|48|58|17|N|111|03|43|W|display=inline|name=Flat Coulee Oil and Gas Field}}, el. {{convert|3570|ft|m}} <ref>{{cite gnis |id=771439|name=Flat Coulee Oil and Gas Field}}</ref> * [[Flat Lake Oil Field]], [[Sheridan County, Montana]], {{coord|48|59|20|N|104|05|07|W|display=inline|name=Flat Lake Oil Field}}, el. {{convert|2178|ft|m}} <ref>{{cite gnis |id=799086|name=Flat Lake Oil Field}}</ref> * [[Fred and George Creek Oil and Gas Field]], [[Toole County, Montana]], {{coord|48|56|35|N|111|27|25|W|display=inline|name=Fred and George Creek Oil and revision.comment: v1.39 - Repaired 1 link to disambiguation page - [[WP:DPL|(You can help)]] - [[Plasma cannon]] per [[WP:INTDABLINK]]
revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=May 2009}} A '''magnetic weapon''' is one that uses magnetic fields to accelerate or stop projectiles, or to focus charged particle beams. There are many hypothesised magnetic weapons, such as the [[railgun]] and [[coilgun]] which accelerate a [[magnetic]] (in the case of railguns; non-magnetic) mass to a high velocity, or [[ion cannon]]s and [[Plasma cannon (disambiguation)|plasma cannon]]s which focus and direct charged particles using magnetic fields.
[[Railgun]]s use two parallel metal rails connected to a power supply. When a conductive projectile is placed between the rails, the circuit is completed and a magnetic field is created down the rails up to the point of the projectile. This creates a force which pushes the projectile along the track, accelerating it to great speeds until it leaves the rails and the circuit is broken.
[[Coilgun]]s, on the other hand, have a barrel made up of coils of magnetic material. The projectile is placed between the coils, which have a pulse of electricity passed through them. This pulls the projectile into the centre of the coil. The coils further down the track are then pulsed in sequence at specific times, accelerating the projectile until it leaves the barrel.
[[Ion cannon]]s are [[directed-energy weapon|beam weapon]]s that fire beams of [[ion]]s (particles, i.e. [[atom]]s that have been affected in some way as to cause them to gain an [[electrical]] charge). Ion cannons are actually [[particle cannon]]s; only the particles used are ionized. Due to their electrical charges, the fired ions also have the potential to disable electronic devices, vehicles, and anything else that has an electrical or similar power source. The inspiration for this effect arises from the [[electromagnetic pulse]] generated by nuclear detonations, which can be devastating to electronic devices.
==See also== *[[Railgun]] *[[Coilgun]] *[[Ion cannon]] *[[Plasma cannon (disambiguation)|Plasma cannon]] *[[List of plasma (physics) articles]]
== External links == *[http://www.keelynet.com/energy/entebbe.htm The Hurwich Ray] A discussion about a magnetic weapon that was reportedly used in the rescue of 103 hijack hostages from [[Entebbe]] Airport on July 3, 1976
[[Category:Proposed weapons]] [[Category:Energy weapons]]
{{Weapon-stub}}

revision.comment: /* See also */
revision.text:
'''Medical cybernetics''' is a branch of [[cybernetics]] which has been heavily affected by the development of the [[computer]],<ref>Brian H. Rudall (2000). "Cybernetics and systems in the 1980s". In: ''Kybernetes''. Vol 29. Issue 5/6 p.595-611.</ref> which applies the concepts of cybernetics to [[medical research]] and practice. It covers an emerging working program for the application of [[systems theory|systems]]- and [[communication theory]], [[connectionism]] and [[decision theory]] on biomedical research and health related questions.
== Overview == Medical cybernetics searches for quantitative descriptions of biological dynamics.<ref name="JWD04">J.W. Dietrich (2004), [http://www.medical-cybernetics.de/definition.html ''Medical Cybernetics – A Definition''], Medizinische Kybernetik, 2004. Released under creative commons 2.0 attribution licence.</ref> It investigates intercausal networks in [[human biology]], [[Decision-making|medical decision making]] and [[information processing]] structures in the [[living organism]].
Topics in medical cybernetics: * [[Systems theory]] in medical sciences: The scope of systems theory in the medical sciences is searching for and modelling of physiological dynamics in the intact and diseased organism to gain deeper insights into the organizational principles of life and its perturbations.<ref name="JWD04"/> * Medical information and [[communication theory]]: Motivated by the awareness of information as an essential principle of life the application of communication theory to biomedicine aims to mathematically describe signalling processes and information storage in different physiological layers.<ref name="JWD04"/> * [[Connectionism]]: Connectionistic models describe information processing in neural networks – thus forming a bridge between biological and technological research.<ref name="JWD04"/> * Medical decision theory (MDT): The Goal of MDT is to gather evidence based foundations for decision making in the clinical setting.<ref name="JWD04"/>
== See also == {{Col-begin}} {{Col-break}} ;Related fields * [[Biocybernetics]] * [[Complex systems]] * [[Cybernetics]] * [[Systems theory]] * [[Prosthetics]] {{Col-break}} ;Related scientists * [[William Ross Ashby]] * [[Claude Bernard]] * [[Valentin Braitenberg]] * [[Walter Cannon]] * [[Stephen Grossberg]] * [[Humberto Maturana]] * [[Warren McCulloch]] {{Col-break}} ;Related scientists * [[Walter Pitts]] * [[Arturo Rosenblueth]] * [[Robert Trappl]] * [[Francisco Varela]] * [[Frederic Vester]] * [[Kevin Warwick]] * [[Paul Watzlawick]] {{col-end}} * [[List of biomedical cybernetics software]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== Further reading == * V.V. Parin (1959), "Introduction to medical Cybernetics" in ''NASA Technical Translation'' no.F-459-F-462, National Aeronautics and Space Administration, 1959. * C.A. Muses (1965). "Aspects of some crucial problems in biological and medical cybernetics". In: ''Progress in biocybernetics'', 1965.
== External links == * [http://www.ai.meduniwien.ac.at/ Institute for Medical Cybernetics and Artificial Intelligence, Medical University Vienna, Austria] * [http://open-site.org/Science/Mathematics/Applied/Cybernetics/K3_-_Applied_Cybernetics/Medical/ Medical Cybernetics in the Open Encyclopedia Project] * [http://www.medizinische-kybernetik.de/ Portal Server Medizinische Kybernetik | Medical Cybernetics] * [http://biocyb.cs.ucla.edu/ UCLA Biocybernetics Laboratory, Los Angeles, Ca, USA]
{{Cybernetics}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Medical Cybernetics}} [[Category:Biomedical cybernetics]]

revision.comment: Adding [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "An ocean on the margin of Gondwana between the Middle Cambrian and Late Triassic" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|An ocean on the margin of Gondwana between the Middle Cambrian and Late Triassic}} [[Image:Paléotéthys.jpg|thumb|Location of the Paleo-Tethys Ocean circa 280 million years ago]] The '''Paleo-Tethys''' or '''Palaeo-Tethys Ocean''' was an [[ocean]] located along the northern margin of the [[paleocontinent]] [[Gondwana]] that started to open during the [[Middle Cambrian]], grew throughout the [[Paleozoic]], and finally closed during the Late [[Triassic]]; existing for about 400 million years.<ref>{{Harvnb|Zhai|Jahn|Wang|Hu|2015|loc=Abstract}}</ref>
Paleo-Tethys was a precursor to the [[Tethys Ocean]] (also called the Neo-Tethys) which was located between Gondwana and the [[Hunic terranes]] (continental fragments that broke-off Gondwana and moved north). It opened as the [[Proto-Tethys Ocean]] subducted under these terranes and closed as the [[Cimmeria (continent)|Cimmerian terranes]] (that also broke-off Gondwana and moved north) gave way to the Tethys Ocean.<ref>{{Harvnb|Muttoni|Gaetani|Kent|Sciunnach|2009|loc=Fig. 2, p. 19}}</ref> Confusingly, the Neo-Tethys is sometimes defined as the ocean south of a hypothesised mid-ocean ridge separating Greater Indian from Asia, in which case the ocean between Cimmeria and this hypothesised ridge is called the Meso-Tethys, i.e. the "Middle-Tethys".<ref>{{Harvnb|Müller|Seton|2015|p=5}}</ref>
The so-called Hunic terranes are divided into the ''European Hunic'' (today the [[Crust (geology)|crust]] under parts of Europe – called [[Armorican terrane|Armorica]] – and [[Iberian Peninsula|Iberia]]) and ''Asiatic Hunic'' (today the crust of parts of southern Asia). A large [[transform fault]] separated the two [[terrane]]s.
The role the Paleo-Tethys played in the [[supercontinent cycle]], and especially the break-up of [[Pangaea]], is unresolved. Some geologists argue that the opening of the North Atlantic was triggered by the subduction of [[Panthalassa]] under the western margins of the Americas while other argue that the closure of the Paleo-Tethys and Tethys resulted in the break-up. In the first scenario, [[mantle plume]]s caused the opening of the Atlantic and the break-up of Pangaea and the closure of the Tethyan domain was one of the consequences of this process; in the other scenario, the longitudinal forces that closed the Tethyan domain were transmitted latitudinally in what is today the Mediterranean region, resulting in the initial opening of the Atlantic.<ref>{{Harvnb|Keppie|2015a|loc=Abstract}}; {{Harvnb|Keppie|2015b|loc=Abstract}}</ref>
==History== [[Image:290 global.png|right|200px|thumb|Image of Paleo-Tethys Ocean, before the Cimmerian Plate moves north, which made the ocean closed, the Paleo-Tethys Ocean closed off about 180 mya. ~290 mya (Early Permian).]] [[Image:249 global.png|right|200px|thumb|The Cimmerian plate starts to move northward, closing the Paleo-Tethys Ocean, while the Tethys Ocean begins to open from the south. ~249 mya (Permian-Triassic boundary).]]
The Paleo-Tethys Ocean began to form when [[Back-arc basin|back-arc]] spreading separated the European Hunic terranes from Gondwana in the late [[Ordovician]], to begin moving toward [[Euramerica]] (also known as the Old Red Sandstone Continent) in the north. In the process, the plate under the [[Rheic Ocean]] between Euramerica and the European Hunic terranes subducted and [[rift]]s in this plate resulted in the formation of a small [[Rhenohercynian Basin|Rhenhercynian Ocean]] which lasted until Late Carboniferous time.<ref>{{Harvnb|Stampfli|von Raumer|Borel|2002|loc=Middle Devonian Phase, p. 272}}</ref><ref name="Stampfli-etal-2002-fig3">{{Harvnb|Stampfli|von Raumer|Borel|2002|loc=Fig. 3, pp. 268–629}}</ref>
In the Early [[Devonian]], the eastern part of Paleo-Tethys opened up, when the Asiatic Hunic terranes, including the [[North China (continent)|North]] and [[South China (continent)|South China]] microcontinents, moved northward.<ref name="Stampfli-etal-2002-fig3" /><ref>{{Harvnb|Stampfli|von Raumer|Borel|2002|loc=Hun Superterrane, p. 267}}</ref>
These events caused [[Proto-Tethys Ocean]], a precursor of Paleo-Tethys, to shrink, until the Late [[Carboniferous]], when the Chinese blocks collided with [[Siberia (continent)|Siberia]].<ref name="Stampfli-etal-2002-fig3" /> In the Early Carboniferous however, a [[Subduction|subduction zone]] developed south of the European Hunic terranes consuming Paleo-Tethys [[oceanic crust]]. <ref>{{Harvnb|Stampfli|von Raumer|Borel|2002|loc=European Hunic active margin in Armorica (''sensu lato''), p. 273}}</ref> Gondwana started moving north, in the process the western part of the Paleo-Tethys would close.<ref name="Stampfli-etal-2002-fig3" /><ref>{{Harvnb|Stampfli|von Raumer|Borel|2002|loc=Fig. 4e, p. 270}}</ref>
In the Carboniferous [[continental collision]] took place between the Old Red Sandstone Continent and the European Hunic terrane, in [[North America]] this is called the [[Alleghenian orogeny]], in [[Europe]] the [[Variscan orogeny]]. The [[Rheic Ocean]] had completely disappeared, and the western Paleo-Tethys was closing.
By the Late [[Permian]], the small elongated [[Cimmerian plate]] (today's crust of [[Turkey]], [[Iran]], [[Tibet]] and parts of [[South-East Asia]]) broke away from Gondwana (now part of [[Pangaea]]). South of the Cimmerian continent a new ocean, the [[Tethys Ocean]], was created. By the Late [[Triassic]], all that was left of the Paleo-Tethys Ocean was a narrow seaway.
In the Early [[Jurassic]] epoch, as part of the [[Alpine Orogeny]], the oceanic crust of the Paleo-Tethys subducted under the Cimmerian plate, closing the ocean from west to east. A last remnant of Paleo-Tethys Ocean might be an oceanic crust under the [[Black Sea]]. ([[Anatolia]], to the sea's south, is a part of the original Cimmerian continent that formed the southern boundary of the Paleo-Tethys.)
The Paleo-Tethys Ocean sat where the [[Indian Ocean]] and [[Southern Asia]] are now located. The [[Equator]] ran the length of the sea, giving it a tropical climate. The shores and islands probably supported dense [[coal forest]]s.

revision.comment: add authority control, test using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{more citations needed|date=August 2010}} '''Peter Anthony Rose''' [[Order of the British Empire|MBE]] (music) and '''Anne Conlon''' [[Order of the British Empire|MBE]] (words) are award-winning writers best known for their environmental musicals for children. They were both teachers in [[Lancashire]], England, for the majority of their creative achievements and most of their works have been written specially for [[St Augustine's RC High School, Billington]]. At the time Peter Rose was their head of music. == Notable works == Rose and Conlon's first collaboration was ''The Conversion Job'' (1980–1); a currently unpublished musical which told the story of Augustine and his monks as they tried to convert Britain to Christianity. This was first performed at St Augustine's RC High School. Their second collaboration was the choral piece ''The Kestrel Song'' (1982), which was later published by their publishers [[Josef Weinberger]] (1995). This piece describes
"the thoughts of a [[kestrel]] as it hovers above the motorway… From the safety of the sky, the Kestrel watches "all the madness of these men rushing blindly onwards". The fog descends, but the traffic rushes on, until the inevitable disaster happens1"
''The Kestrel Song'' won them the ''1982 BBC Pebble Mill – WWF Sounds Natural'' competition, which brought the writers to the attention of Ivan Hattingh, Head of Development at [[World Wide Fund for Nature|WWF]]-UK at the time. Shortly after this, Ivan Hattingh called the writers and asked them to write an extended musical, similar to ''The Kestrel Song'', but about the [[Amazon Basin|Amazon]] [[Rainforest]]. Although it seemed an impossible task, they accepted and penned the first half of ''Yanomamo'' (1983), which described the beauties of the Amazon rainforest. By the second half, which contrasts the lighter first, the writers explore the human problems that existed in the Amazon basin at the time, and ask strong questions about western attitudes to tribal societies and our role in protecting such important and sensitive natural balances. ''Yanomamo'' is a 90-minute work for chorus, soloists, narrator and stage band, and the original production, performed by the choir and musicians of St Augustine's RC High School, was narrated by [[David Attenborough|Sir David Attenborough]] and premiered at the Royal Institute, London, before appearing at the [[Edinburgh Festival]]. They later performed ''Yanomamo'' in America, narrated by [[Sting (musician)|Sting]], which production was recorded for television and later broadcast (on Easter Sunday, 1989) on [[Channel 4]] under the title of ''Song of the Forest''. The TV version was commercially released by WWF. Since its publication the musical has seen performances by thousands of children throughout the world. This interest was also helped by the inclusion of ''Yanomamo'' as part of the [[BBC Radio]] Music Workshop series for schools (1991), including a short dramatic script specially written for the series by Conlon. After the TV adaption was broadcast, the school was officially recognised when two of the young soloists were presented to the [[Duke of Edinburgh]] and presented with the Ford European Conservation Award in the [[Royal Opera House]], [[Covent Garden]]. Rose and Conlon's next collaboration was in 1985 with ''Daughters of Pendle''. This fully dramatic musical explores 16th-century witchcraft in Lancashire, and was first performed by St Augustine's RC High School. The show is currently unpublished. After the highly successful ''Yanomamo'', Ivan Hattingh commissioned Rose and Conlon to write another musical, outlining the severe problems of migration from the countryside to the cities in developing countries. ''African Jigsaw'' (1986) was written and first performed by the choir and musicians of St Augustine's RC High School at the [[Barbican Centre|Barbican Concert Hall]], London, narrated by actress [[Mary Miller (actress)|Mary Miller]] and winning a Henry Ford Conservation Award2. ''African Jigsaw'' was also performed by the school at the [[Royal Festival Hall]] in 1987, this time with Sir [[Charles Groves]] and the Philharmonic Orchestra at a Royal Gala charity performance for the homeless. Again, this musical is a 90-minute work for chorus, soloists, narrator and stage band. ''African Jigsaw'' was later transmitted as a Splash Special by [[ITV Network|ITV]] in 1987, and also part of the ITV Middle English series. Conlon's narration explores the thoughts of one central character; an African mother who has stayed in the countryside whilst her son has started a new life for himself in the city. Three years later saw their third WWF commission, ''Ocean World'' (1990). This time they focused on the problems that threaten the existence of the sea. ''Ocean World'' tells the story of a female [[humpback whale]] as she journeys to her northern feeding grounds. We are with her at the birth to her first calf, and along her journey we meet other creatures of the deep who have their own problems to contend with. Ocean World premiered at the Royal Festival Hall by the choir and musicians of St Augustine's RC High School and was narrated by Sir David Attenborough. A television version, currently available from WWF-UK, was made and transmitted in 1991 as part of Channel 4's ''Fragile Earth'' series. The work follows the same pattern as their previous WWF commissions, and is a 90-minute work for chorus, soloists, narrator and stage band. Rose and Conlon are also known for writing work with a Christian message. In 1987, they were commissioned to write a Harvest Festival Anthem, "Care for your World", which was performed on BBC's ''[[Songs of Praise]]''. Two years later, in March 1989 their hymns were featured in ''[[The Daily Service]]'' on [[BBC Radio 4]]. Rose and Conlon did not collaborate after this until 1996, with the publication of their hymn book ''Hymns for a Caring World'', and their fourth WWF-UK commission ''Arabica'', inspired by a conference Conlon attended about world economics. ''Arabica'' is a musical about the coffee industry and the people involved in the growing, producing and selling of it.[http://www.wwf.org.uk/about_wwf/working_with_schools/resources_hub/musicals/ "Musicals for schools"], WWF. This was premiered at the [[Queen Elizabeth Hall]], London, by the choir and musicians of St Augustine's RC High School with narration by actor [[Burt Caesar]]. ''Arabica'' is arguably the most musically complex of their shows, and most controversial, and has never been broadcast. There was question whether they would write another large-scale musical after ''Arabica'', but in 2000 they wrote ''Song of Creation'' to celebrate the millennium. ''Song of Creation'', unlike their WWF musicals, was written for the catholic charity [[CAFOD]], and premiered at the Royal Festival Hall, London. However, they kept their regular blueprint of writing for chorus, soloists, narrator and stage band. The original production of ''Song of Creation'' was narrated by Mary Miller, who also narrated their ''African Jigsaw'' in 1986. By contrast to their WWF musicals, ''Song of Creation'' has no story as such, yet explores the wonders of creation and of human initiative, at the same time addressing the question of human responsibility for this human drive. Effectively, Rose and Conlon's latest work completes their cycle of environmental musicals by exploring the whole of the world in which we live; the natural balances that occur (which are also explored particularly in ''Yanomamo'' with regards to the rainforest), and the linking together of Western and Developing cultures (which is a theme that runs throughout their work, especially in ''African Jigsaw''). Two new works by Rose and Conlon premiered in 2009. The first, commissioned by Children's International Voices of Enfield, is a smaller piece, ''Caledonian Shadows'', and was performed in London on Sunday 15 March. The second work is a full-length WWF-Commission, ''One Sun, One World'' and was performed at the [[Royal Albert Hall]] at the end of the year.[http://www.wwf.org.uk/about_wwf/working_with_schools/resources_hub/musicals/one_sun_one_world_musical/about_one_sun__one_world_musical/ "About One Sun One World musical"], WWF. They were both appointed [[Member of the Order of the British Empire]] (MBE) in the [[2016 New Year Honours]] for services to musical education and conservation.{{London Gazette|issue=61450|supp=y|pages=N18–N23|date=30 December 2015}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.roseconlonmusic.co.uk Official website] *https://web.archive.org/web/20071026164130/http://www.josef-weinberger.com/weinberger/rep/afrjig.html {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rose, Peter}} [[Category:Songwriting teams]] [[Category:British Roman Catholics]] [[Category:English Roman Catholics]] [[Category:British lyricists]] [[Category:British composers]] [[Category:British nature writers]] [[Category:Writing duos]] [[Category:Members of the Order of the British Empire]] [[Category:Place of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]

revision.comment: /* Polymers */
revision.text:
[[File:Piezoelectric balance presented by Pierre Curie to Lord Kelvin, Hunterian Museum, Glasgow.jpg|thumb|265px|Piezoelectric balance presented by [[Pierre Curie]] to [[Lord Kelvin]], Hunterian Museum, Glasgow]] '''Piezoelectricity''' is the [[electric charge]] that accumulates in certain solid materials (such as [[crystal]]s, certain [[ceramic]]s, and biological matter such as bone, [[DNA]] and various [[protein]]s){{cite book |title=Principles of Instrumental Analysis |edition=6th |year=2007 |first=F. James |last=Holler |last2=Skoog |first2=Douglas A. |last3=Crouch |first3=Stanley R. |lastauthoramp=yes |page=9 |publisher=Cengage Learning |isbn=978-0-495-01201-6}} in response to applied [[Stress (mechanics)|mechanical stress]]. The word ''piezoelectricity'' means electricity resulting from pressure and latent heat. It is derived from the [[Greek language|Greek]] word {{lang|grc|πιέζειν}}; ''piezein'', which means to squeeze or press, and {{lang|grc|ἤλεκτρον}} ''ēlektron'', which means [[amber]], an ancient source of electric charge.{{OEtymD|piezoelectric}}{{LSJ|pie/zw|πιέζειν}}, {{LSJ|h)/lektron|ἤλεκτρον|ref}}. French physicists [[Jacques Curie|Jacques]] and [[Pierre Curie]] discovered piezoelectricity in 1880.{{cite journal | last1=Manbachi |first1=A. |last2=Cobbold |first2=R.S.C. |lastauthoramp=yes |title= Development and Application of Piezoelectric Materials for Ultrasound Generation and Detection |journal= Ultrasound |volume=19 |issue=4 |pages=187–96 |year=2011|doi= 10.1258/ult.2011.011027}} The piezoelectric effect results from the linear electromechanical interaction between the mechanical and electrical states in crystalline materials with no [[Centrosymmetry|inversion symmetry]].{{cite book |title=Piezoelectric Sensorics: Force, Strain, Pressure, Acceleration and Acoustic Emission Sensors, Materials and Amplifiers|isbn=978-3-662-04732-3|doi=10.1007/978-3-662-04732-3|year=2002 |first=G. |last=Gautschi |publisher=Springer}} The piezoelectric effect is a [[reversible process (thermodynamics)|reversible process]]: materials exhibiting the piezoelectric effect (the internal generation of electrical charge resulting from an applied mechanical [[force]]) also exhibit the reverse piezoelectric effect, the internal generation of a mechanical strain resulting from an applied electrical field. For example, [[lead zirconate titanate]] crystals will generate measurable piezoelectricity when their static structure is deformed by about 0.1% of the original dimension. Conversely, those same crystals will change about 0.1% of their static dimension when an external electric field is applied to the material. The inverse piezoelectric effect is used in the production of ultrasonic sound waves.{{cite book |title=Ultrasonic Testing of Materials |date=1990 |last1=Krautkrämer |first1=J. |last2=Krautkrämer |first2=H. |lastauthoramp=yes |publisher=Springer |isbn=978-3-662-10680-8}}{{Page needed|date=July 2018}} Piezoelectricity is exploited in a number of useful applications, such as the production and detection of sound, piezoelectric [[inkjet printing]], generation of high voltages, electronic frequency generation, [[microbalance]]s, to drive an [[ultrasonic nozzle]], and ultrafine focusing of optical assemblies. It forms the basis for a number of scientific instrumental techniques with atomic resolution, the [[scanning probe microscopy|scanning probe microscopies]], such as [[scanning tunneling microscopy|STM]], [[atomic force microscopy|AFM]], [[microthermal analysis|MTA]], and [[scanning near-field optical microscopy|SNOM]]. It also finds everyday uses such as acting as the ignition source for [[lighters|cigarette lighters]], and push-start [[Barbecue#Natural gas and propane|propane barbecues]], as well as being used as the time reference source in [[Quartz clock|quartz watches]]. {{toclimit|3}} ==History== ===Discovery and early research=== The [[pyroelectricity|pyroelectric effect]], by which a material generates an [[electric potential]] in response to a temperature change, was studied by [[Carl Linnaeus]] and [[Franz Aepinus]] in the mid-18th century. Drawing on this knowledge, both [[René Just Haüy]] and [[Antoine César Becquerel]] posited a relationship between mechanical stress and electric charge; however, experiments by both proved inconclusive.{{cite web|last=Erhart |first=Jiří |url=https://moodle.fp.tul.cz/nano/pluginfile.php/2476/mod_resource/content/3/FPM_Piezo_lecture1.pdf |title=Piezoelectricity and ferroelectricity: Phenomena and properties |publisher=Department of Physics, Technical University of Liberec |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140508030117/https://moodle.fp.tul.cz/nano/pluginfile.php/2476/mod_resource/content/3/FPM_Piezo_lecture1.pdf |archivedate=May 8, 2014 }} The first demonstration of the direct piezoelectric effect was in 1880 by the brothers [[Pierre Curie]] and [[Jacques Curie]].{{cite journal|first1=Jacques|last1=Curie|author1-link=Jacques Curie |first2=Pierre |last2=Curie|author2-link=Pierre Curie |date=1880 |title=Développement par compression de l'électricité polaire dans les cristaux hémièdres à faces inclinées |trans-title=Development, via compression, of electric polarization in hemihedral crystals with inclined faces |journal=Bulletin de la Société Minérologique de France |volume=3 |pages=90–93}}
Reprinted in: {{cite journal |first1=Jacques |last1=Curie |author1-link=Jacques Curie |first2=Pierre |last2=Curie |author2-link=Pierre Curie |date=1880 |url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k30485/f296.image |title=Développement, par pression, de l'électricité polaire dans les cristaux hémièdres à faces inclinées |journal=Comptes Rendus |volume=91 |pages=294–295 |language=French |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121205083302/http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k30485/f296.image |archivedate=2012-12-05 |df= }}
See also: {{cite journal|first1=Jacques|last1=Curie|author1-link=Jacques Curie|first2=Pierre|last2=Curie|author2-link=Pierre Curie|date=1880|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k30485/f385.image|title=Sur l'électricité polaire dans les cristaux hémièdres à faces inclinées|trans-title=On electric polarization in hemihedral crystals with inclined faces|journal=Comptes Rendus|volume=91|pages=383–386|language=French|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121205090430/http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k30485/f385.image|archivedate=2012-12-05|df=}} They combined their knowledge of pyroelectricity with their understanding of the underlying crystal structures that gave rise to pyroelectricity to predict crystal behavior, and demonstrated the effect using crystals of [[tourmaline]], [[quartz]], [[topaz]], [[sugar cane|cane]] [[sugar]], and [[Rochelle salt]] (sodium potassium tartrate tetrahydrate). Quartz and Rochelle salt exhibited the most piezoelectricity. [[Image:SchemaPiezo.gif|thumb|A piezoelectric disk generates a voltage when deformed (change in shape is greatly exaggerated)]] The Curies, however, did not predict the converse piezoelectric effect.
