As Acting Administrator of GSA, Kline worked to restore independence<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OPqORWzoNZ8C&pg=PA100&lpg=PA100&dq=ray+kline+congressional+record&source=bl&ots=VeSN_GVpT-&sig=XxXTUcudVAo4sQm4KZTD8W2HeS8&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjd49HF_bPWAhXGPiYKHTacBQwQ6AEILzAC#v=onepage&q=ray%20kline%20congressional%20record&f=false|title=Diary of a Dream: A History of the National Archives Independence Movement, 1980-1985|last=Warner|first=Robert M.|date=1995-01-01|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=9781461658054}}</ref> of the [[National Archives]] from GSA and directly contributed to passage of the [https://www.archives.gov/about/laws National Archives and Records Administration Act of 1984].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/readingroom/docs/CIA-RDP92B01283R000100070017-1.pdf|title=NATIONAL ARCHIVES AND RECORDS ADMINISTRATION ACT OF 1984|last=|first=|date=|website=CIA|access-date=}}</ref><ref name="NARA Act">{{cite web|url=http://www.justice.gov/osg/briefs/1985/sg850113.txt|title=DOJ, Passage of NARA|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100522035019/http://www.justice.gov/osg/briefs/1985/sg850113.txt|archivedate=2010-05-22|df=}}</ref> After his retirement in 1985 from public service after 33 years in the [[Federal government]], Kline became President<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.nap.edu/read/1617/chapter/28?term=kline#374|title=Appendix N {{!}} Finding Common Ground: U.S. Export Controls in a Changed Global Environment {{!}} The National Academies Press|doi=10.17226/1617}}</ref> of the National Academy of Public Administration (NAPA), a non-partisan, nonprofit corporation established in 1967 and chartered by [[United States Congress|Congress]] to provide research and counsel to increase the effectiveness of American government at all levels. Kline served as NAPA's president from 1985 to 1992.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.napawash.org/fellows/our-fellows/mr-ray-kline|title=National Academy Of Public Administration|website=National Academy Of Public Administration|access-date=2018-04-12}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/20040071104.pdf|title=SUMMARY REPORT OF THE NASA MANAGEMENT STUDY GROUP, RECOMMENDATIONS TO THE ADMINISTRATOR|last=Phillips|first=S. C.|date=December 30, 1986|website=|access-date=}}</ref> During this time at NAPA, Kline appeared before several congressional committees to provide testimony on various topics.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.c-span.org/person/?raykline|title=Ray Kline {{!}} C-SPAN.org|website=www.c-span.org|access-date=2017-09-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/20040071104.pdf|title=NAPA Recommendations to NASA Study Group|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.fedsmith.com/2010/10/17/how-federal-employees-see-themselves-seen/|title=How Federal Employees See Themselves (And Are Seen): One Man's Opinion : FedSmith.com|last=|first=|date=April 12, 2018|work=FedSmith.com|access-date=April 12, 2018}}</ref> Since retirement in 1992, Kline was voted onto the Board of the [http://www.thekerrfoundation.org/ Kerr Foundation], a non-profit charitable and educational organization in [[Oklahoma]], where he served until 2009.<ref name="Kerr Foundation">{{cite web|url=http://research.unm.edu/nmfd/KerrFoundation.cfm|title=Kerr Foundation|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100607205946/http://research.unm.edu/nmfd/KerrFoundation.cfm|archivedate=2010-06-07|df=}}</ref> Kline also served on other boards including the [http://www.procurementroundtable.org/ Procurement Round Table]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.procurementroundtable.org/documents/Acquisition%20Leadership.pdf|title=Acquisition Leadership, PRT Letter - Procurement Round Table|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref><ref name="Procurement Round Table">{{cite web|url=http://www.procurementroundtable.org/Directors.htm|title=Procurement Round Table|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20050709081302/http://www.procurementroundtable.org/Directors.htm|archivedate=2005-07-09|df=}}</ref> and the [[Roger W. Jones Award for Executive Leadership]] at [[American University]].<ref name="Roger W. Jones Award for Executive Leadership">{{cite web|url=http://www.american.edu/spa/dpap/Roger-Jones-Nomination.cfm|title=Roger W. Jones Award for Executive Leadership}}</ref> Kline also holds the top awards from three Federal agencies: the [[NASA Distinguished Service Medal]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://history.nasa.gov/SP-4012/vol4/appa.htm|title=appa|website=history.nasa.gov|access-date=2017-09-19}}</ref>[https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19940029443.pdf],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19940029443.pdf|title=NASA HISTORICAL DATA BOOK Volume IV NASA Resources 1969- 1978|last=Fedor|first=Helen|date=1994|website=|access-date=}}</ref> the [https://www.gsa.gov/ GSA Distinguished Service Award] and the [https://www.archives.gov/files/about/history/sources/reports/1985-annual-report.pdf Archivists' Distinguished Service Award]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.archives.gov/files/about/history/sources/reports/1985-annual-report.pdf|title=National Archives Annual Report 1985|last=National Archives|first=|date=April 12, 2018|website=|access-date=}}</ref> from the [[National Archives and Records Administration]].
==Personal life== After retiring in 1992, Kline remained in the Maryland suburbs of Washington, D.C., serving on several [[advisory board]]s. He enjoyed his family, travel, and various intellectual pursuits. Kline married Jeanelle Batley April 26, 1958, and they had two children: Robin Jeanelle (b. 1962) Raymond Ashley (b. 1969).
==References== {{Reflist}}
*''Who's Who in America'' 1992-1993, 47th Edition, Volume 1 A-K *''Procurement Round Table''[https://archive.is/20050709081302/http://www.procurementroundtable.org/Directors.htm] *''World Statesmen''[http://www.worldstatesmen.org/USA_govt2.html] *''NASA''[https://history.nasa.gov/augustine/racfup7.htm] *''Highbeam''[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-1083021.html] *''National Academy of Public Administration''<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OOhgASjTS0EC&pg=PA196&lpg=PA196&dq=%22ray+kline%22+%22congressional%22&source=bl&ots=m2UIzksrb-&sig=gbejfzneKQLTWBIltXzA6PE5eCE&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiYvdK4p7XaAhUq_4MKHdbnCVk4ChDoAQgsMAI#v=onepage&q=%22ray%20kline%22%20%22congressional%22&f=false|title=Doctoral Education at the Washington Public Affairs Center: 28 Years (1973-2001) as an Outpost of the University of Southern California|last=Sherwood|first=Frank P.|date=December 2008|publisher=iUniverse|isbn=9781440106231}}</ref> *''NASA History''[http://history.msfc.nasa.gov/management/org_charts/4-08-10-62.pdf][https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19940029443.pdf][https://www.jsc.nasa.gov/history/oral_histories/FisherAL/FisherAL_Bio.pdf]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.jsc.nasa.gov/history/oral_histories/FisherAL/FisherAL_Bio.pdf|title=NASA JOHNSON SPACE CENTER ORAL HISTORY PROJECT BIOGRAPHICAL DATA SHEET|last=Fisher|first=Anna|date=2011|website=|access-date=}}</ref> *''Apollo Program/Marshall Reconstruction''[https://history.nasa.gov/SP-4102/notes.htm] *''American Technology Alliances (AmTech)''[https://web.archive.org/web/20110903233119/http://www.amtech-usa.org/boardmembers.html] *''Roger W. revision.text:
{{short description|American writer}} [[File:Rick Bass.jpg|thumb|Rick Bass in 2015]]
'''Rick Bass''' (born March 7, 1958) is an American [[writer]] and an [[environmental activist]].<ref name=utexas >{{cite web|title=A Guide to the Rick Bass Papers, 1982-1994|url=http://www.lib.utexas.edu/taro/tsusm/00005/tsu-00005.html|publisher=University of Texas|work=Southwest Writer's Collection|accessdate=July 25, 2011}}</ref>
==Life== Bass was born in [[Fort Worth, Texas]], United States,<ref name="utexas"/> the son of a geologist, and he studied [[petroleum geology]] at [[Utah State University]]. He grew up in Houston, and started writing short stories on his lunch breaks while working as a petroleum geologist in [[Jackson, Mississippi]]. In 1987, he moved with his wife, the artist [[Elizabeth Hughes Bass]], to the remote [[Yaak Valley]], where he works to protect his adopted home from roads and logging. Rick serves on the board of both the Yaak Valley Forest Council and Round River Conservation Studies. He continues to give readings, write, and teach around the country and world.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.narrativemagazine.com/authors/rick-bass |title=Rick Bass |publisher=Narrative Magazine |date= |accessdate=2014-07-09}}</ref>
His papers are held at the Southwest Collection/Special Collections Library at [[Texas Tech University]]<ref>[http://www.lib.utexas.edu/taro/tturb/00151/trb-00151.html "Rick Bass: An Inventory of His Papers, 1958-2001 and undated"]</ref> and [[Texas State University–San Marcos]].<ref name="utexas"/>
==Awards== Bass won The [[Story Prize]] for books published in 2016 for his collection of new and selected stories, ''For a Little While''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sfchronicle.com/books/article/Rick-Bass-wins-Story-Prize-10987832.php |title=Rick Bass wins Story Prize |work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] |author=John McMurtrie |date=March 8, 2017}}</ref> He won the 1995 [[James Jones Literary Society First Novel Fellowship]] for his novel in progress, ''Where the Sea Used to Be''.<ref>[http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1995-11-06/features/9511060003_1_fiction-award-largest-literary-award-willys-dream-kit "Carl Sandburg Awards Bestowed On 4 Local Writers"], by John Blades, ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'', November 06, 1995.</ref> He was a finalist for the [[Story Prize]] in 2006 for his short story collection ''The Lives of Rocks''. He was a finalist for the 2008 [[National Book Critics Circle Award]] (autobiography) for ''[[Why I Came West]]'' (2009). He was also awarded the General Electric Younger Writers Award, a PEN/Nelson Algren Award Special Citation for fiction, and a National Endowment for the Arts fellowship.
==Works==

Norton & Company| year= 1994| isbn= 978-0-393-31135-8 }} (Originally published 1989) * {{Cite book| title=Platte River| revision.text:
{{primary sources|date=May 2017}} {{refimprove|date=July 2012}} '''Shell Processing Support''' ('''SPS''') is a set of formatted files used for exchanging Land 3D seismic data. They can also be used for 2D.
==History== Shell Processing Support data format was initially defined and used by Shell Internationale Petroleum for transferring of seismic and positioning data to the processing centres. In 1993 [[Society of Exploration Geophysicists|SEG]] Technical standards committee on ancillary data formats adopted SPS as the standard format for exchanging Geophysical positioning data.<ref>{{cite journal | url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1190/1.1443799 | title=Shell Processing Support Format for Land 3-D Surveys | author=Shell Internationale Petroleum Maatschappij B.V., The Hague, The Netherlands | journal=Geophysics |date=March–April 1995 | volume=60 | pages=596 | doi=10.1190/1.1443799}}</ref>
==SPS Format== SPS format is a set of three files called Receiver file, Source file, Cross reference file and an optional fourth file for comments. In addition to the comment file comments can be entered in each of the three files as part of the header and is indicated by starting with the letter H.
'''Receiver file''': Receiver file contains the information about the geophones their type, position ([[Easting]], [[Northing]], [[Elevation]]) and their ID.
'''Source file''': Source file contains the information about the [[Seismic source]] its position and their ID.
'''Cross reference file''': Cross reference file (also known as relational file) or in short, X file, is basically a relational file relating the source and the receiver when the shot occurred. It contains the details about the Shot ID, Source and receivers associated with that particular shot ID.
'''Comment file''': This file is an optional file. Any other information regarding the seismic acquisition can be provided in this file for the processing center.
==Versions== * The first version of SPS adopted by SEG is now referred to as SPS rev0 * The recent version of SPS is SPS rev2.1
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.seg.org/resources/publications/misc/technical-standards Standards adopted by the SEG including SPS rev0 (1995) and rev2.1 (2006)] * [http://geophysics.geoscienceworld.org/content/60/2/596.abstract Shell processing support format for land 3-D surveys]
{{Geophysics navbox}} {{Petroleum industry}}
[[Category:Geophysics]] [[Category:Petroleum industry]]

revision.text:
{{wiktionary|shittah}} '''Shittah tree'''<ref>Isaiah 41:19</ref> ([[Hebrew language|Hebrew]]: שטה) or the plural "[[shittim (disambiguation)|shittim]]" <ref>Exodus 25:10 & 23, 26:15</ref> was used in the [[Tanakh]] to refer to trees belonging to the genus ''[[Vachellia]]'' and the genus ''[[Faidherbia]]''. ''[[Faidherbia albida]]'', ''[[Vachellia seyal]]'', ''[[Vachellia tortilis]]'', and ''[[Vachellia gerrardii]]'' can be found growing wild in the [[Sinai peninsula|Sinai]] desert and the [[Jordan River|Jordan]] valley.
[[File:Trees and shrubs. Shittim tree at Engedi. (Ancacia Seyal Del.) LOC matpc.14961.tif|thumb|right|450|A Shittah tree]]
In [[the Exodus]], the ancient [[Israelites]] were commanded to use '''shittah wood''' to make various parts of the [[Tabernacle (Judaism)|Tabernacle]] and of the [[Ark of the Covenant]]. This was most likely the ''[[Acacia seyal]]''.{{fact|date=July 2017}}
"The wild acacia (''[[Vachellia nilotica]]''), under the name of ''sunt'', everywhere represents the ''seneh'', or ''senna'', of the [[burning bush]]. A slightly different form of the tree, equally common under the name of ''[[Vachellia seyal|seyal]]'', is the ancient ''shittah'', or, as more usually expressed in the plural form, the ''shittim'', of which the Tabernacle was made."<ref>[[Arthur Penrhyn Stanley]], ''Sinai and Palestine''.</ref>
==See also== *''[[Sideroxylon lanuginosum]]'', a North American native plant sharing common names with the Biblical shittah tree *''[[Xylosma maidenii]]'', an Australian native plant known as shitum wood
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== *{{CathEncy|wstitle=acacia}} *[[Arthur Penrhyn Stanley]], ''Sinai and Palestine''. *[[Book of Exodus|Exodus]] chapter 25, verses 10, 13, 23, and 28.
[[Category:Torah]] [[Category:Plants in the Bible]] [[Category:Plant common names]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2018}} {{About|the current and future tropical cyclone lists|the history of naming|History of tropical cyclone naming|previously named storms|List of historical tropical cyclone names{{!}}Historical tropical cyclone names}} {{Tropicalcyclone}} [[Tropical cyclone]]s and [[subtropical cyclone]]s are named by various warning centers to provide ease of communication between forecasters and the general public regarding forecasts, watches, and warnings. The names are intended to reduce confusion in the event of concurrent storms in the same [[Tropical cyclone basins|basin]]. Generally once storms produce sustained wind speeds of more than {{convert|33|kn|km/h mph}}, names are assigned in order from predetermined lists depending on which basin they originate. However, standards vary from basin to basin: some tropical depressions are named in the Western Pacific, while tropical cyclones must have a significant amount of [[gale]]-force winds occurring around the centre before they are named in the [[Southern Hemisphere]]. Before the formal start of naming, tropical cyclones were named after places, objects, or saints' feast days on which they occurred. The credit for the first usage of personal names for weather systems is generally given to the [[Queensland Government]] Meteorologist [[Clement Wragge]], who named systems between 1887 and 1907. This system of naming weather systems subsequently fell into disuse for several years after Wragge retired, until it was revived in the latter part of [[World War II]] for the Western Pacific. Formal naming schemes and naming lists have subsequently been introduced and developed for the [[Pacific hurricane|Eastern, Central]], [[Typhoon|Western]] and [[South Pacific tropical cyclone|Southern Pacific]] basins, as well as the [[Australian region tropical cyclone|Australian region]], [[Atlantic Ocean]] and [[Indian Ocean]]. {{TOC limit|limit=2}} ==History== {{main article|History of tropical cyclone naming|List of historic tropical cyclone names}}

Before the formal start of naming, tropical cyclones were often named after places, objects, or saints' feast days on which they occurred.{{cite web|title=They Called the Wind Mahina: The History of Naming Cyclones|url=ftp://ftp.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/pub/dorst/Mahina.pptx|work=Hurricane Research Division, Atlantic Oceanographic and Meteorological Laboratory|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|author=Dorst, Neal M|at=Slides 8–72|date=October 23, 2012|format=PPTX}} The credit for the first usage of personal names for weather systems is generally given to the [[Queensland Government]] Meteorologist [[Clement Wragge]], who named systems between 1887 and 1907. This system of naming weather systems subsequently fell into disuse for several years after Wragge retired until it was revived in the latter part of [[World War II]] for the Western Pacific. Formal naming schemes have subsequently been introduced for the North Atlantic, Eastern, Central, Western and Southern Pacific basins as well as the Australian region and Indian Ocean. At present, tropical cyclones are officially named by one of eleven warning centers and retain their names throughout their lifetimes to facilitate the effective communication of forecasts and storm-related hazards to the general public.{{cite book|author=Landsea, Christopher W|author2=Dorst, Neal M|date=June 1, 2014|title=Tropical Cyclone Frequently Asked Question|chapter=Subject: Tropical Cyclone Names: B1) How are tropical cyclones named?|publisher=United States National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's Hurricane Research Division|chapterurl=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/tcfaq/B1.html|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6XOuFI8YV?url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/tcfaq/B1.html|archivedate=March 29, 2015|deadurl=no|df=}} This is especially important when multiple storms are occurring simultaneously in the same ocean basin. Names are generally assigned in order from predetermined lists, once they produce one, three, or ten-minute sustained wind speeds of more than {{convert|65|km/h|mph|round=5|abbr=on}}. However, standards vary from basin to basin, with some systems named in the Western Pacific when they develop into tropical depressions or enter PAGASA's area of responsibility. Within the [[Southern Hemisphere]], systems must be characterized by a significant amount of [[gale]]-force winds occurring around the center before they are named. {{anchor|Retirement}}Any member of the [[World Meteorological Organization]]'s hurricane, typhoon and tropical cyclone committees can request that the name of a tropical cyclone be retired or withdrawn from the various tropical cyclone naming lists. A name is retired or withdrawn if a consensus or majority of members agree that the system has acquired a special notoriety, such as causing a large number of deaths and amounts of damage, impact, or for other special reasons. A replacement name is then submitted to the committee concerned and voted upon, but these names can be rejected and replaced with another name for various reasons: these reasons include the spelling and pronunciation of the name, the similarity to the name of a recent tropical cyclone or on another list of names, and the length of the name for modern communication channels such as social media.{{cite web|date=November 10, 2014 |title=Tropical Cyclone Names |url=http://www.bom.gov.au/cyclone/about/names.shtml |publisher=Australian Bureau of Meteorology |accessdate=March 30, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6XP7TIkDS?url=http://www.bom.gov.au/cyclone/about/names.shtml |archivedate=March 30, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }} PAGASA also retires the names of significant tropical cyclones when they have caused at least {{ntsp|1000000000||[[Philippine peso|₱]]}} in damage or have caused at least 300 deaths.{{Cite press release |title=PAGASA replaces names of 2014 destructive typhoons |accessdate=March 30, 2015 |publisher=Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration |url=http://pagasa.dost.gov.ph/index.php/news/92-press-release/682-pagasa-replaces-names-of-2014-destructive-typhoons |date=February 5, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6WMvFku6m?url=http://pagasa.dost.gov.ph/index.php/add-news/2252-pagasa-replaces-names-of-2014-destructive-typhoons |archivedate=February 15, 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ==North Atlantic Ocean== {{see|List of retired Atlantic hurricane names}} [[File:Michael 2018-10-10 1840Z.jpg|thumb|180px|right|[[Hurricane Michael]] nearing peak intensity, October 2018]] Within the North Atlantic Ocean, tropical or subtropical cyclones are named by the [[National Hurricane Center]] (NHC/RSMC Miami) when they are judged to have intensified into a tropical storm with winds of at least {{convert|34|kn|mph km/h|abbr=on}}. There are six lists of names which rotate every six years and begin with the first letters A—W used, skipping Q and U, and alternating between male and female names. The names of significant tropical cyclones are [[List of retired Atlantic hurricane names|retired]] from the lists, with a replacement name selected at the next World Meteorological Organization's Hurricane Committee meeting. If all of the names on a list are used, storms are named after the letters of the [[Greek alphabet]]. {| class="wikitable" |+ List of Atlantic tropical cyclone names |- !scope="col" colspan=12|[[2018 | Lee || Margot || Nigel || Ophelia || Philippe || Rina || Sean || Tammy || Vince || Whitney || |- !colspan=12|References: |} ==Eastern Pacific Ocean== {{see|List of retired Pacific hurricane names}} [[File:Lane_2018-08-21_2350Z.jpg|thumb|180px|right|[[Hurricane Lane (2018)|Hurricane Lane]] near peak intensity in August 2018]] Within the Eastern Pacific Ocean, there are two warning centers that assign names to tropical cyclones on behalf of the World Meteorological Organization when they are judged to have intensified into a tropical storm with winds of at least {{convert|34|kn|mph km/h|abbr=on}}. Tropical cyclones that intensify into tropical storms between the coast of Americas and 140°W are named by the National Hurricane Center (NHC/RSMC Miami), while tropical cyclones intensifying into tropical storms between 140°W and 180° are named by the Central Pacific Hurricane Center (CPHC/RSMC Honolulu). Significant tropical cyclones have their names retired from the lists and a replacement name selected at the next World Meteorological Organization Hurricane Committee. The current naming scheme began with the [[1978 Pacific hurricane season|1978 season]], one year before the Atlantic basin (and which anomalously used the list that will be used next in 2018, rather than the one for 2020). As with the Atlantic basin, it uses alternating women's and men's names, and also includes some Spanish and a few French names. Before then, only women's names were used. Because Eastern Pacific hurricanes mainly threaten western Mexico and Central America, the lists contain more Spanish names than the Atlantic lists. ===North Pacific east of 140°W=== When a tropical depression intensifies into a tropical storm to the north of the Equator between the coastline of the Americas and 140°W, it will be named by the NHC. There are six lists of names which rotate every six years and begin with the letters A—Z used, skipping Q and U, with each name alternating between a male or a female name. The names of significant tropical cyclones are [[List of retired Pacific hurricane names|retired]] from the lists, with a replacement name selected at the next World Meteorological Organization's Hurricane Committee. If all of the names on a list are used, storms are named using the letters of the Greek alphabet. {| class="wikitable" |+ List of Eastern Pacific tropical cyclone names |- !scope="col" || Zelda |- !colspan=13|References: |} ===Central North Pacific Ocean (140°W to 180°)=== [[File:Walaka_2018-10-02_0054Z.jpg|thumb|180px|right|[[Hurricane Walaka]] in October 2018, at peak intensity south of [[Johnston Atoll]]]] When a tropical depression intensifies into a tropical storm to the north of the Equator between 140°W and 180°, it is named by the CPHC. Four lists of [[Hawaiian language|Hawaiian]] names are maintained by the World Meteorological Organization's hurricane committee, rotating without regard to year, with the first name for a new year being the next name in sequence that was not used the previous year. The names of significant tropical cyclones are [[List of retired Pacific hurricane names|retired]] from the lists, with a replacement name selected at the next Hurricane Committee meeting. {| class="wikitable" |+ List of Central Pacific tropical cyclone names |- !scope="col"| List !scope="col" colspan=12| Names |- !scope="row"| 1 | Akoni || Ema || Hone || Iona || Keli || Lala || Moke || Nolo || Olana || Pena || Ulana || Wale |- !scope="row"| 2 | Aka || Ekeka || Hene || Iolana || Keoni || Lino || Mele || Nona || Oliwa || Pama || Upana || Wene |- !scope="row"| 3 | Alika || Ele || Huko || Iopa || Kika || Lana || Maka || Neki || Omeka || Pewa || Unala || Wali |- !scope="row"| 4 | Ana || Ela || Halola || Iune || Kilo || Loke || Malia || Niala || Oho || Pali || Ulika || Walaka |- !colspan=14|References: |} ==Western Pacific Ocean (180° – 100°E)== [[File:Mangkhut_2018-09-12_0150Z.png|thumb|180px|right|[[Typhoon Mangkhut|Typhoon Mangkhut]] at peak intensity in September 2018]] Tropical cyclones that occur within the Northern Hemisphere between the [[180th meridian|anti-meridian]] and [[100th meridian east|100°E]] are officially named by the Japan Meteorological Agency when they become tropical storms. However, [[PAGASA]] also names tropical cyclones that occur or develop into tropical depressions within their self-defined area of responsibility between 5°N–25°N and 115°E-135°E. This often results in tropical cyclones in the region having two names. ===International names=== {{see|List of retired Pacific typhoon names}} Tropical cyclones within the Western Pacific are assigned international names by the JMA when they become a tropical storm with 10-minute sustained winds of at least {{convert|34|kn|mph km/h|abbr=on}}. The names are used sequentially without regard to year and are taken from five lists of names that were prepared by the ESCAP/WMO Typhoon Committee, after each of the 14 members submitted 10 names in 1998. The order of the names to be used was determined by placing the English name of the members in alphabetical order. Members of the committee are allowed to request the [[List of retired Pacific typhoon names#Background|retirement or replacement]] of a system's name if it causes extensive destruction or for other reasons such as number of deaths. Unlike other basins, storms are also named after plants, animals, objects, and mythological beings. {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" |+ List of Western Pacific tropical cyclone names |- !scope="col" rowspan=2 | List !scope="col" colspan=14| Contributing nation |- !scope="col"| Cambodia !scope="col"| China !scope="col"| North Korea

===Philippines=== {{see|List of retired Philippine typhoon names}} [[File:Trami_2018-09-25_0050Z.png|thumb|180px|right|[[2018 Pacific typhoon season#Typhoon Trami|Typhoon Paeng (Trami)]] at peak intensity in September 2018]] Since 1963, PAGASA has independently operated its own naming scheme for tropical cyclones that occur within its own self-defined [[Philippine Area of Responsibility]].{{Cite news|title=Why and how storms get their names|publisher=GMA News|accessdate=December 1, 2016|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/233580/news/nation/why-and-how-storms-get-their-names|date=September 27, 2011}}{{cite web|title=Philippine Tropical cyclone names|publisher=Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration|accessdate=January 17, 2017|url=http://www.pagasa.dost.gov.ph/index.php/learning-tools/94-weather/278-philippine-tropical-cyclone-names|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161228042559/http://www.pagasa.dost.gov.ph/index.php/learning-tools/94-weather/278-philippine-tropical-cyclone-names|archivedate=December 28, 2016|df=}} The names are taken from four different lists of 25 names and are assigned when a system moves into or develops into a tropical depression within PAGASA's jurisdiction. The four lists of names are rotated every four years, with the names of significant tropical cyclones retired should they have caused at least {{ntsp|1000000000||[[Philippine peso|₱]]}} in damage and or at least 300 deaths within the Philippines.{{Cite press release |title=PAGASA replaces Tropical Cyclone "Lando" to "Liwayway" |accessdate=November 4, 2015 |publisher=Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration |url=https://web.pagasa.dost.gov.ph/index.php/news/92-press-release/682-pagasa-replaces-names-of-2014-destructive-typhoons |deadurl=yes Auxiliary || Alamid || Bruno || Conching || Dolor || Ernie || Florante || Gerardo || Hernan || Isko || Jerome || || || |- !colspan=20|References: |} ==North Indian Ocean (45°E – 100°E)== [[File:Ockhi 2017-12-02 Suomi NPP.jpg|thumb|180px|right|[[Cyclone Ockhi]] near its peak intensity in November 2017]] Within the North Indian Ocean between 45°E – 100°E, tropical cyclones are named by the India Meteorological Department (IMD/RSMC New Delhi) when they are judged to have intensified into a cyclonic storm with 3-minute sustained wind speeds of at least {{convert|34|kn|mph km/h|abbr=on}}.{{cite book|title=Tropical Cyclone Operational Plan for the Bay of Bengal and the Arabian Sea: 2015|publisher=World Meteorological Organization|accessdate=September 2, 2015|url=http://www.wmo.int/pages/prog/www/tcp/documents/TCP-21Edition2015_final.pdf|edition=2015|pages=11–12}} There are eight lists of names which are used in sequence and are not rotated every few years; however, the names of significant tropical cyclones are retired.{{cite web|title=Naming of Cyclones over the North Indian Ocean |url=http://www.rsmcnewdelhi.imd.gov.in/images/pdf/cyclone-awareness/tc-names/tc-names.pdf |publisher=India Meteorological Department |accessdate=November 28, 2016 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6mMqJFm4O?url=http://www.rsmcnewdelhi.imd.gov.in/images/pdf/cyclone-awareness/tc-names/tc-names.pdf |archivedate=November 28, 2016 |deadurl=yes |df= }} {| class="wikitable" |+ List of Northern Indian Ocean tropical cyclone names |- !scope="col" rowspan=2 | List !scope="col" colspan=8| Contributing nation |- !scope="col"| Bangladesh !scope="col"| India !scope="col"| Maldives !scope="col"| Myanmar !scope="col"| Oman !scope="col"| Pakistan !scope="col"| Sri Lanka !scope="col"| Thailand |- !scope="row" | 1 | [[Cyclone Onil|Onil]] || [[Cyclone Agni|Agni]] || [[Cyclone Hibaru|Hibaru]] || [[Cyclone Pyarr|Pyarr]] || [[Cyclone Baaz|Baaz]] || [[Cyclone Fanoos|Fanoos]] || [[Cyclone Mala|Mala]] || Mukda |- !scope="row" | 2 | [[Cyclone Ogni|Ogni]] || [[Cyclone Akash|Akash]] || [[Cyclone Gonu|Gonu]] || [[Cyclone Yemyin|Yemyin]] || [[Cyclone Sidr|Sidr]] || [[Cyclone Nargis|Nargis]] || [[Cyclone Rashmi|Rashmi]] || Khai-Muk |- !scope="row" | 3 | [[Cyclone Nisha|Nisha]] || [[Cyclone Bijli|Bijli]] || [[Cyclone Aila|Aila]] || [[Cyclone Phyan|Phyan]] || [[Cyclone Ward|Ward]] || [[Cyclone Laila|Laila]] || [[Cyclone Bandu|Bandu]] || Phet |- !scope="row" | 4 | [[Cyclone Giri|Giri]] || [[Cyclone Jal|Jal]] || [[Cyclone Keila|Keila]] || [[Cyclone Thane|Thane]] || [[Cyclone Murjan|Murjan]] || [[Cyclone Nilam|Nilam]] || [[Cyclone Viyaru|Viyaru]] || [[Cyclone Phailin|Phailin]] |- !scope="row" | 5 | [[Cyclone Helen|Helen]] || [[Cyclone Lehar|Lehar]] || [[Cyclone Madi|Madi]] || [[Cyclone Nanauk|Nanauk]] || [[Cyclone Hudhud|Hudhud]] || [[Cyclone Nilofar|Nilofar]] || [[Cyclone Ashobaa|Ashobaa]] || [[Cyclone Komen|Komen]] |- !scope="row" | 6 | [[Cyclone Chapala|Chapala]] || [[Cyclone Megh|Megh]] || [[Cyclone Roanu|Roanu]] ||Kyant|| [[Cyclone Nada|Nada]] ||[[Cyclone Vardah|Vardah]]|| [[Cyclone Maarutha|Maarutha]] || [[Cyclone Mora|Mora]] |- !scope="row" | 7 | [[Cyclone Ockhi|Ockhi]] || [[Cyclone Sagar|Sagar]] || [[Cyclone Mekunu|Mekunu]] ||Daye|| [[Cyclone Luban|Luban]] || [[Cyclone Titli|Titli]] ||Gaja|| Phethai |- !scope="row" | 8 | Fani || Vayu || Hikaa || Kyarr || Maha || Bulbul || Pawan || Amphan |- !colspan=11|References: |} {{Clear}} ==South-West Indian Ocean (Africa – 90°E)== [[Image:Enawo 2017-03-07 0606Z.png|thumb|right|180px|[[Cyclone Enawo]] nearing landfall in [[Madagascar]] in March 2017]] Within the South-West Indian Ocean in the Southern Hemisphere between Africa and 90°E, a tropical or subtropical disturbance is named when it is judged to have intensified into a tropical storm with winds of at least {{convert|34|kn|mph km/h|abbr=on}}.{{cite web|url=http://www.meteo.fr/temps/domtom/La_Reunion/webcmrs9.0/anglais/activiteope/liste_noms.html |deadurl=no |author=La Reunion Tropical Cyclone Centre |title=How are the names chosen? |date=August 31, 2015 |accessdate=September 1, 2015 |archivedate=September 1, 2015 |publisher=Météo-France |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6bE12GKGj?url=http://www.meteo.fr/temps/domtom/La_Reunion/webcmrs9.0/anglais/activiteope/liste_noms.html |df= }} This is defined as being when gales are either observed or estimated to be present near a significant portion of the system's center. Systems are named in conjunction with [[Météo-France]] Reunion by either Météo Madagascar or the Mauritius Meteorological Service. If a disturbance reaches the naming stage between Africa and 55°E, then Météo Madagascar names it; if it reaches the naming stage between 55°E and 90°E, then the Mauritius Meteorological Service names it. The names are taken from three pre-determined lists of names, which rotate on a triennial basis, with any names that have been used automatically removed. The names that are going to be used during a season are selected in advance by the World Meteorological Organization's RA I Tropical Cyclone Committee from names submitted by member countries. {| class="wikitable" |+ List of South–West Indian Ocean tropical cyclone names |- !scope="col" colspan=14|2018-19 |- !scope="row" rowspan=2|Names | Alcide || Bouchra || Cilida || Desmond || Eketsang || Funani || Gelena || Haleh || Idai || Joaninha || Kenneth || Lorna || Maipelo |- | Njazi || Oscar || Pamela || Quentin || Rajab || Savana || Themba || Uyapo || Viviane || Walter || Xangy || Yemurai || Zanele |- !scope="col" colspan=14|2019-20 |- !scope="row" rowspan=2|Names | Ambali || Belna || Calvinia || Diane || Esami || Francisco || Gabekile || Herold || Irondro || Jeruto || Kundai || Lisebo || Michel |- | Nousra || Olivier || Pokera || Quincy || Rebaone || Salama || Tristan || Ursula || Violet || Wilson || Xila || Yekela || Zania |- !scope="col" colspan=14|2020–21{{#tag:ref|The names Ava through Fakir were automatically removed from the naming lists during the [[2017–18 South-West Indian Ocean cyclone season]]. No replacement names have been chosen.|group="nb"}} |- !scope="row" rowspan=2|Names |''Ava''||''Berguitta''||''Cebile''||''Dumazile''||''Eliakim''||''Fakir''|| Guambe || Habana || Iman || Jobo || Kanga || Ludzi || Melina |- | Nathan || Onias || Pelagie || Quamar || Rita || Solani || Tarik || Urilia || Vuyane || Wagner || Xusa || Yarona || Zacarias |- ! colspan=14|References:{{cite news|title=Tropical Cyclone Naming|url=https://www.wmo.int/pages/prog/www/tcp/Storm-naming.html|accessdate=June 27, 2016|publisher=World Meteorological Organization}} |} {{clear}} ==Australian Region (90°E – 160°E)== {{see|List of retired Australian cyclone names}} Within the Australian region in the Southern Hemisphere between 90°E – 160°E, a tropical cyclone is named when observations or [[Dvorak technique|Dvorak intensity analysis]] indicate that a system has gale force or stronger winds near the center which are forecast to continue. The Indonesian [[Indonesian Meteorological and Geophysical Agency|Badan Meteorologi, Klimatologi, dan Geofisika]] names systems that develop between the Equator and 10°S and 90°E and 141°E, while Papua New Guinea's National Weather Service names systems that develop between the Equator and 10°S and 141°E and 160°E. Outside of these areas, the Australian [[Bureau of Meteorology]] names systems that develop into tropical cyclones. In order to enable local authorities and their communities in taking action to reduce the impact of a tropical cyclone, each of these warning centres reserve the right to name a system early if it has a high chance of being named. If a name is assigned to a tropical cyclone that causes loss of life or significant damage and disruption to the way of life of a community, then the name assigned to that storm is [[List of retired Australian cyclone names|retired from the list of names]] for the region. A replacement name is then submitted to the next World Meteorological Organization's RA V Tropical Cyclone Committee meeting. ===Indonesia=== If a system intensifies into a tropical cyclone between the Equator-10°S and 90°E-141°E, it will be named by the [[Indonesian Agency for Meteorology, Climatology and Geophysics|Badan Meteorologi, Klimatologi, dan Geofisika]] (BMKG/TCWC Jakarta). Names are assigned in sequence from list A, while list B details names that will replace names on list A that are retired or removed for other reasons. {| class="wikitable" style="float:left" |+ List of Indonesian tropical cyclone names |- !scope="col" colspan=10|List A |- | Anggrek || Bakung || Cempaka || Dahlia || Flamboyan || Kenanga || Lili || Mangga || Seroja || Teratai |- !scope="col" colspan=10|List B |- | Anggur || Belimbing || Duku || Jambu || Lengkeng || Melati || Nangka || Pisang || Rambutan || Sawo |- !colspan=10|References:{{cite web|accessdate=April 11, 2015|title=Cyclone Names|publisher=Badan Meteorologi, Klimatologi, dan Geofisika|url=http://meteo.bmkg.go.id/siklon/name|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150316103748/http://meteo.bmkg.go.id/siklon/name|archivedate=March 16, 2015|deadurl=no}} |} {{clear}} ===Papua New Guinea=== If a system intensifies into a tropical cyclone between the Equator – 10°S and 141°E – 160°E, then it will be named by Papua New Guinea National Weather Service (NWS, TCWC Port Moresby). Names are assigned in sequence from list A and are automatically retired after being used regardless of any damage caused. List B contains names that will replace names on list A that are retired or removed for other reasons. {| class="wikitable" style="float:left" |+ List of Papua New Guinea tropical cyclone names |- !scope="col" colspan=10|List A |- | scope="row" | Alu || Buri || Dodo || Emau || Fere || Hibu || Ila || Kama || Lobu || Maila |- !scope="col" colspan=10|List B |- | scope="row" | Nou || Obaha || Paia || Ranu || Sabi || Tau || Ume || Vali || Wau || Auram |- !colspan=10|References: |} {{Clear}} ===Australia=== {{anchor|Australia}} [[File:Debbie 2017-03-28 0010Z.jpg|thumb|180px|right|[[Cyclone Debbie]] making landfall over [[Queensland]] in March 2017]] When a system develops into a tropical cyclone below 10°S between 90°E and 160°E, then it will be named by the Australian [[Bureau of Meteorology]] (BoM) which operates three [[Bureau of Meteorology|Tropical Cyclone Warning Centres]] in [[Perth]], [[Darwin, Northern Territory|Darwin]], and [[Brisbane]]. The names are assigned in alphabetical order and used in rotating order without regard to year. {| class="wikitable" |+ List of Australian tropical cyclone names |- !scope="col" colspan=12|List A |- !scope="row" rowspan=2|Names | Anika || Billy || Charlotte || Dominic || Ellie || Freddy || Gabrielle || Herman || Ilsa || Jasper || Kirrily |- || Lincoln || Megan || Neville || Olga || Paul || Robyn || Sean || Tasha || Vince || Zelia || ------ |- !scope="col" colspan=12|List B |- !scope="row" rowspan=2|Names | Anthony || Bianca || Courtney || Dianne || Errol || Fina || Grant || Hayley || Iggy || Jenna || Koji |- || Luana || Mitchell || Narelle || Oran || Peta || Riordan || Sandra || Tim || Victoria || Zane ||------ |- !scope="col" colspan=12|List C |- !scope="row" rowspan=2|Names | Alessia || Bruce || Catherine || Dylan || Edna || Fletcher || Gillian || Hadi || Ivana || Jack || Kate |- || Laszlo|| Mingzhu || Nathan || Olwyn || Quincey || Raquel || Stan || Tatiana || Uriah || Yvette ||------ |- !scope="col" colspan=12|List D |- !scope="row" rowspan=2|Names | Alfred || Blanche || Caleb || Dara || Ernie || Frances || Greg || Hilda || Irving || Joyce || Kelvin |- || Linda || Marco || Nora || Owen || Penny || Riley || Savannah || Trevor || Veronica || Wallace||------ |- !scope="col" colspan=12|List E |- !scope="row" rowspan=2|Names | Ann || Blake || Claudia || Damien || Esther || Ferdinand || Gretel || Harold || Imogen || Joshua || Kimi |- || Lucas || Marian || Niran || Odette || Paddy || Ruby || Seth || Tiffany || Vernon ||------||----- |- !colspan=12|References: |} ==Southern Pacific Ocean (160°E – 120°W)== [[File:Donna 2017-05-08 0230Z.jpg|thumb|180px|right|[[Cyclone Donna]] in May 2017, the strongest off-season cyclone in the South Pacific]] {{anchor|South Pacific}} {{see|List of retired South Pacific cyclone names}} Within the Southern Pacific basin in the Southern Hemisphere between 160°E – 120°W, a tropical cyclone is named when observations or [[Dvorak technique|Dvorak intensity analysis]] indicate that a system has gale force or stronger winds near the centre which are forecast to continue. The [[Fiji Meteorological Service]] (FMS) names systems that are located between the Equator and 25°S, while the New Zealand [[MetService]] names systems (in conjunction with the FMS) that develop to the south of 25°S. In order to enable local authorities and their communities in taking action to reduce the impact of a tropical cyclone, the FMS reserves the right to name a system early if it has a high chance of being named. If a tropical cyclone causes loss of life or significant damage and disruption to the way of life of a community, then the name assigned to that cyclone is [[List of retired South Pacific tropical cyclone names|retired from the list of names]] for the region. A replacement name is then submitted to the next [[World Meteorological Organization]]'s RA V Tropical Cyclone Committee meeting. The name of a tropical cyclone is determined by using Lists A — D in order, without regard to the year before restarting with List A. List E contains names that will replace names on A-D when needed. {| class="wikitable" |+ List of South Pacific tropical cyclone names |- !scope="col" colspan=14|List A |- !scope="row" rowspan=2|Names | Ana || Bina || Cody || Dovi || Eva || Fili || Gina || Hale || Irene || Judy || Kevin || Lola || Mal |- | Nat || Osai || Pita || Rae || Seru || Tam || Urmil || Vaianu || Wati || Xavier || Yani || Zita || |- ! scope="col" colspan=14|List B |- !scope="row" rowspan=2|Names | Arthur || Becky || Chip || Denia || Elisa || Fotu || Glen || Hettie || Innis || Julie || Ken || Lin || Maciu |- | Nisha || Orea || Pearl || Rene || Sarah || Troy || Uinita || Vanessa || Wano ||------|| Yvonne || Zaka || |- ! scope="col" colspan=14|List C |- !scope="row" rowspan=2|Names | Alvin || Bune || Cyril || Daphne || Eden || Florin || Garry || Haley || Isa || June || Kofi || Louise || Mike |- | Niko || Opeti || Perry || Reuben || Solo || Tuni || Ulu || Victor || Wanita ||------|| Yates || Zidane || |- ! scope="col" colspan=14|List D |- !scope="row" rowspan=2|Names | Amos || Bart || Crystal || Dean || Ella || Fehi || Garth || Hola || Iris || Jo || Kala || Liua || Mona |- | Neil || Oma || Pola || Rita || Sarai || Tino || Uesi || Vicky || Wasi ||------|| Yolanda || Zazu || |- ! scope="col" colspan=14|List E (Standby) |- !scope="row" rowspan=2|Names | Aru || Ben || Chris || Danial || Emosi || Feki || Germaine || Hart || Ili || Jose || Kirio || Lute || Mata |- | Neta || Olivia || Pana || Rex || Samadiyo || Tasi || Uila || Velma || Wane ||------|| Yasa || Zanna || |- !colspan=14|References: |} ==South Atlantic== When a tropical or subtropical storm exists in the South Atlantic Ocean, the [[Brazilian Navy|Brazilian Navy Hydrographic Center]]'s Serviço Meteorológico Marinho names the system using a predetermined list of names. The names are assigned in alphabetical order and used in rotating order without regard to year. {| class="wikitable" |+ List of South Atlantic tropical cyclone names |- !scope="row" |Names | Arani || Bapo || Cari || Deni || Eçaí || Guará || Iba || Jaguar || Kurumí || Mani || Oquira || Potira || Raoni || Ubá || Yakecan |- !colspan=16|References: |} ==See also== {{Portal|Tropical cyclones}} revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta)
revision.text:
A '''tylosis''' (plural: '''tyloses''') is a bladder-like distension of a parenchyma cell into the lumen of adjacent vessels in wood. Less certainly, the term '''tylosis''' is in use to summarise the physiological process and the resulting occlusion in the [[xylem]] of woody plants as response to injury or as protection from decay in heartwood.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://encarta.msn.com/dictionary_561509079/tylosis.html|title=MSN online dictionary|accessdate=19 February 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100421031737/http://encarta.msn.com/dictionary_561509079/tylosis.html|archivedate=21 April 2010|df=}}</ref> It is a key process in wall one of the [[Compartmentalization Of Decay In Trees]] (CODIT) and other woody plants.
[[File:Carpinus betulus1 cross beentree.jpg|thumb|right|Section of ''[[Carpinus betulus]]'' wood showing the distinctive dark areas created as a result of tylosis in response to fungal infection]]
==Anatomy== Observed in section under a microscope, tyloses appear as balloon-like protrusions emanating from axial paratracheal [[parenchyma]] cells into xylem vessels through pits linking the two. In some types, there may be a distinct barrier between the tyloses emanating from the pits into the vessels, while they may be barely distinguishable in other cases.<ref>{{cite book|last=Shigo|first=Alex L.|authorlink=Alex Shigo|title=Modern Arboriculture- A systems approach to the care of trees and their associates|edition=third (2003)|year=1991|isbn=0943563097 |pages=56–57}}</ref>
==Role in compartmentalization== Tylosis in [[Flowering plant|narrow vesseled plant]] vessels counteracts the axial spread of fungal [[hypha]]e and other pathogens by slowing down their vertical spread with a physical barrier. A similar process occurs in [[gymnosperm]]s, which block access to [[tracheid]]s by closing the pits that join them to each other.<ref name=Weber>{{cite book|last1=Weber|first1=K.|last2=Mattheck|first2=C.|title=Manual of wood decays in trees|year=2003|publisher=The Arboricultural Association|location=Romsey, Hampshire|isbn=0-900978-35-X|pages=27–28}}</ref>
The blocked vessels also provide a defense against the radial spread of pathogens, limiting their horizontal spread through the plant stem. Protection is stronger at the boundaries where [[Dendrochronology|annual rings]] meet.
The effectiveness of both vertical and horizontal barriers is affected by the speed at which they are established by tyloses, being typically faster in healthier plants.<ref name=Weber/>
==Role in heartwood formation== As a tree grows, its [[Cambium (botany)|cambium]] adds an annual increment (or ring) of new wood, and in many species of trees the older wood towards the centre of the tree becomes less important for physiological processes like water and nutrient transportation, and this is converted by the tree to [[heartwood]]. This [[heartwood]] has no active defenses against infection, but is protected from infection and decay by the blockage of the xylem vessels with tyloses and various substances such as gums, [[resin]]s and waxes containing high concentrations of [[volatile organic compound]]s such as [[terpene]]s that are toxic to insect larvae and tree pathogens such as bacteria and fungi. These products are produced by the cambium and transported to the centre of the stem by cellular structures called [[Medullary ray (botany)|medullary rays]] radiating from the center of the stem <ref>{{cite book|last=Page |first=Jake|author2=Editors of Time-Life Books |title=Forest|series=Planet Earth|year=1983|publisher=Time-Life Books, Amsterdam|isbn=0 7054 0752 7|page=176}}</ref> and then enter living axial paratracheal [[parenchyma]] cells. As the wood ages, the contents of the parenchyma cell burst into the dead vessel through the pit linking the two. The parenchyma cell then dies as its contents are disgorged into the empty space of the dry vessel and highly effective decay-inhibiting substances, notably tannin, are formed and absorbed by the adjacent vessel walls.
==External links== {{Portal|Trees}} * [http://www.dutchelmdisease.org/EXPERT/DED/CORE/00/01/E2.HTML Pictures of tylosis in ''Ulmus'' (Elm), with detailed description of the process]
==Sources== {{Reflist}}
